description:
Why 5 stars? Because chicken tikka masala fries, obviously!

   ---   ---   ---

I don't have a ton to say in this review, outside of re-stating what I ordered:

Chicken
Tikka
Masala
Fries

Once I type those four words, it doesn't feel like I should have to do any further explaining as to why I've chosen 5-stars for this review. I mean, I guess the tikka masala could have been sub-par, but I would have mentioned that already by this point. It was perfect - I only wish I'd had more.

To make an already great thing even better - I snagged a grilled cheese sandwich from another truck (Upper Cut) and these fries served as my side item. This could not have been a more perfect marriage. These two trucks should definitely combine to form one business and call this combination "Party In My Mouth." They'd make millions - both dollars and smiles.
author: Brett N.

description:
NO CASH ACCEPTED 
Credit ONLY!!

I've stopped going. 

I understand their friends over at Señor Sisig did this first and I cut them out as well.

The CTM (Chicken Tiki Masala) burrito is always good but having no choice but to use my ATM card sucks. I understand the argument and I'm sure the line moves much faster but what happens when I'm Will Smith in, Enemy of the State!?

Go back and read my previous review; the food here stands out, especially since it's a truck. Get the CTM the first week and then branch out. It's all good!
author: Justin S.

description:
This is my om nom nom. You can't go wrong no matter what you order - samosa, burrito, bowl - they've taken familiar favorites, added a little innovation and fun, and amped up the flavor. My favorite fatty option is the paneer sexy fries: criss-cross sweet potato fries covered in curry goodness. It's not just the catchy name; it's bury-your-face-in-it deliciousness that will leave you full half way through but you won't be able to stop eating because it's so good. Any amount of gym time is worth it.

Definitely order online and feel like a rockstar when you cut to the front of that long line of folks who know what's up.
author: Cristina S.

description: I've only tried the chicken tikka masala burrito and mango lassi from this location. The flavors are good with a nice kick of spice. It's one of those places I don't frequent often but it is a nice change of pace compared to the usual sandwich/salad/pizza lunch spots near the office. The mango lassi paired with the main dish is a nice dessert/treat to calm the spiciness of the burrito. Expect long lines to order but they prep the food pretty quick.
author: Sandy L.

description: Ordered lamb kathi roll and was really impressed by the authentic flavour. The food truck seemed to be popular as it had a queue even at non peak time. The flavours were nicely blended.
author: Sharad B.

description:
Indian spice and all things nice... that's what you get when you order from the Curry Up Now Food Truck.

I've had the pleasure of eating their food a couple of times. Once at a local Farmers Market Festival, and most recently, at a work event. Their Chicken Tikka Masala is probably the best I've ever had. The sauce has plenty of tomato/creamy goodness with just enough kick (but not too much). It comes with turmeric white rice, chana garbanzo masala, and pico kachumbe. What really makes this dish stand out is the succulent chicken. It's perfectly cooked. Never dry. Always tender. 

If you're looking for a quick meal that's more portable, I'd highly recommend one of their burritos. My favorites are the Tikka Masala and the Ghee Makhni Butter burrito. Each burrito comes in a flour tortilla, with turmeric white rice, chana garbanzo masala, and sliced onions. De-lish!

There are other things on the menu that I'm still eager to try, including: the Kashmiri Lamb rice bowl, the Naughty Naan, the Indian Tacos, and Sexy Fries (an Indian-inspired poutine - criss cut sweet potato fries, cheese, and your choice of protein).

I can't recommend this food truck enough. They take Indian "street food" to a whole new level!
author: Kevin B.

description:
Curry Up Now has been on my bucket list for quite some time. 

I didn't know they had a food truck in the financial district that is regularly operating during the weekdays. 

While leaving Target on Bush Street, I saw their food truck and was starving. It was only appropriate to check these guys out once and for all. 

I had fun reading their menu - it has a ton of interesting and unique things to offer. Their sexy fries and chicken tikka masala burrito are eye catching and definitely worth coming back to try. And anything listed under the naughty naan section on the menu 

I ended up ordering their vegan quesadillix. They offer paneer (vegan) or chicken with this entree, chaat masala yogurt and chutney wrapped in potato wheat. I am a week day vegetarian so, naturally I opted for meat free. 

The portion was HUGE and a bit too much to eat for lunch but that didn't stop me from trying... I had a second lunch later that day. No regrets! But come hungry. 

The service was quick and the staff was friendly. 

I plan on coming back to try other unique food Curry Up Now. I love the creative thoughts and American spin they add to their food.
author: Ashley L.

description:
Tried this food truck for lunch and woah!  I ordered the "naughty naan" w/ chicken tikka masala and OMG.  It's basically a flatbread of naan with chicken tikka masala, caramelized onions, jalapenos, and cheese!  It was absolutely delicious and its a huge serving -- I'd recommend sharing it for two people.

I also ordered a side of the sweet potato waffle fries and NOM - these were also really good.

Overall, the food is fun, different, and delicious!  & they make it pretty quickly, I don't think I was standing there for longer than 5 minutes - so great for lunch time while at work.  I'd definitely recommend and will return for more.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Place - It is food truck. You can check where is it on yelp. It is pink truck . 

Taste - I ordered decon samosa. 

*Decon samosa - it camed with 4 pieces of small samosa and one big samosa. It choosed topping chicken. If you want you can add rice with $1. But for me it was a lot. First time when I got this, it came in small box. I opend it and only 4 small samosa was in it. I was diappointed but under curry there was huge samosa. Curry was good. I liked it. Overall it was pretty good for lunch.

Service and Price - Service was good and Price was reasonbale.
author: Da Won L.

description:
I've went to the location in San Mateo but did not have such a great culinary experience. However, this spot got a second chance when my friend's sister hired this as one of their caterers' for her wedding!

I got the Thali Platter which includes pickled purple cabbage, basmati yellow rice, this chip thing, naan, and your choice of three proteins. I got the Chicken Tikka Masala, Aloo, and the Lentils. Everything was delicious but the chicken was a little spicier than expected. Nonetheless, it was still very good! Being an Indian-Western fusion establishment, they also offer vegan and vegetarian options as well. 

The servers were very quick to take our orders and I had to literally only wait a minute. Although, now thinking about it, they did have to move fairly quickly to feed 200 people. Of course, their menu is more extensive  at their B&M locations, so check it out!
author: Vivian C.

description: The chicken tikka masala burrito was okay. It was a lot of rice and sauce. I'd say the first half was good but afterwards I wanted a different taste.
author: Lillian B.

description: I used to be a fan of Curryupnow ,but over the years, the quality has really gone down. The taste of the food has deteriorated and quantities have reduced. I understand rising inflation affects food cost, but my recent visit was a bummer. I got a deconstructed samosa and chose to have the vegan option. I thought the protein would be substitutes with Tofu or something. But there was no protein at all. But I still paid the same as other options with protein. How is it fair to charge the same if you are not going to serve the same amount of food. On top of it the overall quantity was as good as an appetizer but it cost $9 and change . I can get much better food for that money in downtown SF.
author: Umang D.

description: Yum yum yum! I had the vegan samosas bowl at BottleRock and it hit the spot. It had a great flavor and was very filling. It came out fast and the workers were nice and efficient.
author: Mikala W.

description: Good food. I had the Chicken tikkamasala bowl and it was good but not great.  I may just be one of those people who only like Americanized Indian food, but it lacked that rich butteriness that I love in most that dish. But other than that there was nothing to complain about or rave about. It was fast and filling and got the job done. But with all the options around that city, I probably won't go back.
author: Jeremy N.

description:
Came here because I love curry, food trucks, and after seeing the good reviews.

Food: I got the vegan bowl which was filled with a samosa, garbanzo beans, rice, and some pico. Not the best presentation and it was mainly rice. For $10 I thought it would be a lot more food. Flavors were good, on the spicy side which I don't mind. 

Service: There was no line so I got my food super fast.

Probably won't come back because for the price it's not really worth it. Wasn't bad food, but I've had better curry for sure.
author: Hayley D.

description: Curry Up Now is food truck nirvana! Super delicious Indian food (North Indian style), with plenty options for vegetarians. I'm so glad that they're stationed so close to my work, so I can enjoy them day after day! Long lines are typical at lunch hour, but it's so worth it!
author: Shalom O.

description:
The info is wrong, this place does have wifi, outdoor seating and alcohol! (Overpriced Indian beer though) 

Papdi Chaat: personally prefer a little more chaat but this tasted great! 

Criss cut sweet potato fries: I didn't get the dip but I'd recommend it (+$1) if you're not otherwise getting something with butter masala. 

Tau, the dude: Biryani w/ egg inside samosa shell regally sitting in salan sauce. Hot damn! This is fairly spicy so steer away if only tikka masala is your jam. 

The American Punjabi Thali: amazing butter chicken and aloo gobi but channa masala was just plain weird. Salad sides, naan and rice were up to the mark. 

Service: prompt but GRUFF. Needs work for sure. 

Great choice of music, goes well with the interior and adds to the ambience. Quality is good, so I won't hold it against them for being on the pricier side.
author: Sadia I.

description: I found a piece of clear plastic film in my tikka masala. Walked back and they were gone. Called them and no response. Will not be back.
author: Cal Y.

description: I walk past this food truck everyday. The orange truck is always parked in front of the Target that's located on the corner of Bush St. and Sansome St. There's always a line of customers waiting to order. So today I decided to come here for lunch. I ordered the Deconstructed Samosas $9.00 (made it a rice bowl for $1). It was really good and very filling. I could only eat half. Next I will try the Hella Vegan Burrito in my next visit.
author: Mag D.

description:
Pros
- Interesting food choices 
- Most of the food is good and has a nice amount of spiciness 
- Decent beer selection

Cons
- The staff aren't the friendliest
author: Dipesh G.

description: Tried the curry burrito here during some sort of food truck fest in Berkeley a year ago. It was decent but less flavorful than I expected given the hype for this place - perhaps I ordered the wrong thing?
author: Thomas S.

description:
Ok, I have to admit, when I first heard of Indian Burrito, I was skeptical :-), but let me tell you, it's awesome! a bit spicy, but I push through as it's just soo good :-)

Give it a try, also try the NAUGHTY NAAN.

Please note that, I am vegetarian and only eat the Paneer burrito or NAUGHTY NAAN!
author: Guy L.

description:
If you know what a samosa is, than expect your tastebuds to never return to a typical samosa after you try Curry Up Now's "Deconstructed Samosa." This $8 treat (+$1 to make it a rice bowl) is claimed an inside-out phenomenon! And I can vouch for this flavor blasting bowl of goodness.

What you're receive: Chana masala (a spicy Indian chickpea dish that I absolutely love and am still trying to perfect at home--send me all your favorite recipes!), pico de gallo with chutneys dressed with mini samosas that include your choice of protein: beef, chicken, paneer or vegan option. 

It's spicy, well balanced on the flavor, and will keep your eating until there's none left. The portion is large, this is definitely one meals worth of food or a great dish to split among several people.
author: Rose L.

description:
Tried this at Treasure Island Flea. The naan sandwich was pretty good, but Kathi rolls were bad. It was soggy and flavorless. Portions were small too. We probably didn't order the right items, I will give it a try next time. (The burritos looks good)

Food: 1/5
Price:2/5

Favorites:
* Naughty naan wwith chicken tikka masala ($10) 

Other orders:
* Kathi rolls with beef ($8) - mughlai parantha (pan fried egg washed flat bread), sliced onions & chutney
author: Victoria L.

description: It's always a treat eating a masala burrito. Lines usually isn't that bad during the lunch rush. A few times I ordered a burrito they already had it pre-made.  The burrito is still warm
author: Henry T.

description:
I love the flavor! I've been meaning to try Curry Up Now for a long while. I have even passed by their restaurant at one point, but the people I was with didn't want Indian food! 

I love Indian curries and spices. I was lucky enough to try this food truck while attending an all day conference in SoMa! While we were in line they handed out their samosas. I'm so glad I got to try that. That alone probably would've filled me up and I would've been perfectly happy. I actually couldn't eat it all because I ordered the paneer tikka masala. I loved the garbanzo beans and the rice. The paneer was flavorful and the sauces were a good amount of spicy!

I definitely want to visit their restaurant and try other items on their menu! They were super quick and efficient which I appreciated. I'm not sure what the wait times would be like on a normal day since this was a catered event!
author: Dianna C.

description: They serves so quickly. My gf and I got the food in 3 minutes! Quality was fine, not bad, I like the bean texture of this curry. I would have this again if the restaurants were soso nearby.
author: Changmin L.

description:
I tried the chicken tikka masala burrito with brown rice and a wheat tortilla. I'm glad the order is completely customizable! The burrito was a good size and got me full. I was originally supposed to save half for lunch the next day, but I ended up finishing it because it was so good!!! It definitely gave me a food coma afterwards...

The burrito is super flavorful and is a bit spicy, even though I got mild. It had a good ratio of meat, rice, and other goodies wrapped inside. We got our orders delivered to the office and everything was still hot when we opened them ten minutes after they were delivered. Wahoo!
author: Tara A.

description:
It is definitly not the most flavorful indian food. 
I had the paneer tikka burrito, which had way too much rice.  Supposedly it had onions but I did not see any. 
I got spicy and it was pretty spicey, so next time if I were to get it I would get medium.
author: B P.

description:
Curry fix in the FiDi!  

The spices lack strong flavor or umph.  It was good, nonetheless.  

Got the Tikal masala chicken and it hits the spot. 

Decent lunch spot!
author: Tiffany D.

description: I love Indian food and heard about this spot from my husband. I went here for the first time today and absolutely love it! I ordered the Hella Vegan Burrito which has chana masala, pico, rice and samosa. Burrito was $9.50, decently priced for the amount of food.
author: Bree D.

description:
Tried and true - this is one of the first food trucks I started coming to regularly. I love that I can count on them being on Bush on most days of the week. Yes, there will be a line, but this is DTSF (it comes with the territory). The last he's usually move pretty quickly and I'm on my way. 

It's an interesting take on Indian food. The chicken tikka masala burrito, and the sexy fries are awesome examples of how they have reinvented foods with with an Indian twist. Everything I've gotten here has been good (I think I've had most of the menu items) however, it's the deconstructed samosa that keeps me coming back. Great portion size with mini samosas Chana masala in a bowl. Its awesome and definitely hits the spot when you want something quick with really great flavor with a bit of a kick. A number of Indian food trucks have popped up recently, but curry up now has created something unique. 

I usually go between the chicken and the paneer deconstructed samosa. Make sure to get one with a mango lassi and go eat it on one of the rooftop gardens around FiDi. You're welcome.
author: Thielson D.

description:
Gim'me some TL;DR
- Walk up to the food truck, order, pay, BAM- they hand you the food. The entire interaction takes about 20 seconds. In and out, fo sho. 

How yer experience?
- We went at 1pm on a weekday, and there was no line. I ordered the chicken tikka masala burrito, and my friend ordered the deconstructed samosa. The have the food pre-packed and ready to go, so things are quick. I can appreciate operational efficiencies. 

How da food taste? 
- We both enjoyed the food, though now I am in that post Indian food state. Zzzzz. Ethnic food meets burrito- the trend continues. 

Where da truck at? 
- The truck is located near the Target on Bush Street. 

Where to sit and eat? 
- Go to the nearby One Samsone courtyard. Public space with excellent lighting and lots of tables.
author: Joanna L.

description: I've only ordered once so far through Eat24, and my Hella Vegan Burrito arrived on time and was delicious. It was a little more spicy than I expected (I asked for mild because I have an embarrassingly ridiculous sensitivity to anything stronger than black pepper), but it was still really good. I just needed extra napkins, tissues, and water on hand. The flavors made it worthwhile, and I will definitely order from their menu again.
author: Russ S.

description:
I ordered "Paneer Tikka Masala" vegetarian and was disappointed to find no vegetables other than onions.  

This is the first time for me.  I'll try something else next time.  

I would not rate this food truck high on a value scale.
author: Dennis W.

description: Made it out to this elusive Indian street food truck to try one of their their star dishes - a deconstructed chicken samosa chaat. Honestly nothing deconstructed about it. It was just samosa topped with curry, chutneys, spiced onions and cilantro. They also added small mini samosa toppings for crunch may be. Not my favorite. It tasted real good but not something I plan to queue up for. Will be back to try kathi rolls though.
author: Neha M.

description: Yum!! I used to come here every so often when I was working in the Financial District. Come lunch hour they get pretty busy so if you're craving this spot I'd say arrive early - and bring your appetite! The samosas are the BOMB!!!
author: Katherine D.

description:
I used to be a big fan of Curry Up Burritos. Nothing can beat the taste of PTM or veggie burritos. Introduced it to few of my colleagues. They love the burritos and the Naughty Naan. This became one of the favorite place to order our bi-weekly team lunches. Being a vegetarian, me and wife always like to order Paneer Tikka Masala (PTM) or Punjabi Burrito. 

However, not sure what happened to them off late. They have been messing up with the orders very badly. Not sure if its just me.  Twice during this week, they gave me Chicken Tikka Masala (CTM) Burrito instead of PTM. Having no prior experience of mishandle with the orders, I found something wrong with the order immediately. I went back to the truck and the guy in the counter apologized for the mistake and gave me a PTM burrito. Well, nobody is perfect and we all make mistakes.

Again, today, we decided to order at the same place. This time, I wanted to be 200% sure and digged the top layer to ensure that i got what I ordered. Damn, Chicken burrito again !!  Although they replaced my order, this is really bad and I could never take it. To be cautious, I will never visit this place again
author: Gangadharan R.

description:
Solid lunch spot. 

Has the chicken tikka masala burrito. Ordered and got my food all in less than twenty seconds! $9 and change for a good sized burrito for lunch. Looked small but it was dense and filling. 

The chicken was tender. Good large chunks of meat. The spices were flavorful and left a nice kick after the ritto was gone. 

Food trucks' presence can be hit or miss but I'm glad the hours on Yelp were accurate today!
author: Carissa G.

description: This is a really great option if you're looking for Indian food that's made pretty quickly.  The staff are all very friendly and patient with their customers.  I would highly recommend the Kati Roll - it's basically a roti (think whole wheat version of a tortilla) wrap infused with egg, and then stuffed with a filling (paneer, chicken, or lamb), onions, and peppers.  Regardless of what you get, they have great options for both non-veg and veg eaters alike.  Check it out!
author: Curren I.

description:
The famous chicken tikka burrito is full of flavor and SO satisfying! If you're hesitant like I was ... just try it. Please.

I actually had my order from Curry Up Now delivered to my work by Uber Eats, so all that I can really comment about is the quality of the food but, that being said, it's GOOD! As a lover of both Indian and Mexican food, I was a bit skeptical about seeing these two worlds collide, but they are seriously compatible. The burrito was bursting with the perfect amount of flavor, which was wonderfully complex, and provided the wonderful comfort of hearty Indian food all in the convenience of a whole wheat tortilla. Genius. I just need to remove one star, unfortunately, because admittedly my stomach did not feel too great after eating it :( However, it still tasted really awesome and is a dish that I think any Indian food lover should try at least once!
author: Desiree S.

description:
Curry Up Now was the first food truck I began visiting when I started working downtown. So perhaps nostalgia is to thank for this 5 star review.

Who am I kidding? The quality of the food is to blame for this review! When I first dropped in on this joint I thought, "What a gimmick!" It reminded me of Chipotle but with Tikka Masala. Boy was I wrong.

The Paneer Tikka Masala burrito is one of the most delicious tasting things I have eaten in my entire life! I can't go back to Chipotle after having one of these bad boys. The paneer and garbanzo beans are so tasty it's making me sweat a little bit just typing this.

Really unique and well executed take on Indian food. And in the Bay Area, where you can easily feel overexposed to the plethora of offerings, Curry Up Now stands out for its groovy interpretation of delicious staples. Curry up and try it already!
author: Kevin B.

description: There are lots of desi food options in the bay area. Few try to come up with their own spin on Indian food. I really like how curry up now at least tries. When it works it is great, when it doesn't, it is not that bad either.
author: Saideep S.

description:
I tried Curry Up at the StrEAT Food Park.  The menu sounded pretty exciting and innovative, but the food was missing that Indian umph, that special burst of flavor.  I found all of the entree elements to be far too sweet, from the chana to the chutney to the chicken tikka.  There was no spiciness, either in terms of spices for flavor or hot pepper spice.  It did the trick, but missed the mark for that Indian zest.  The food wasn't bland, but certainly not spiced as I would've expected.  What was excellent, however, was the mango lassi.  The flavor was perfect--just the right amount of mango, the perfect sweetness, and the perfect size for the price.  For me, this item is a definite must try.

What concerns me is that I asked if the inside out samosa had wheat because the menu made no mention of actual samosas or samosa wrappers, and I am very much gluten intolerant.  When I asked, the lady said no, but at the table, before taking a bite, I found the dish to be full of mini samosas, and a large one.  Those are definitely made of flour.  

When I went back up with my dish and asked about it, she still said no flour.  Then, I showed her a mini samosa on the spoon to be sure I had the right dish.  She says yes, right dish, no wheat, just flour.  Everyone makes mistakes, but that could've been a very costly one.  I would've been sick for weeks, at minimum.  Some people would be willing to sue over that, had they eaten it, so hopefully she knows now.  Upon asking, She let me exchange my dish, but she wasn't too enthused.  Sorry, but no fad diet here.  I really can't eat the stuff, as much as is love to.
author: Kristen H.

description:
I'm a little biased because I LOVE the Hella Vegan burrito from their truck. It has samosa, rice, chutney, garbanzo beans, and onions. 
When I stepped into the actual B&M, I was pleased to find out that I can have my choice of a wheat or flour tortilla, and brown or white rice. The truck uses flour tortilla and white rice, so I opted for wheat tortilla and brown rice.

There were many times I would get a Hella Vegan burrito off the truck for lunch wishing I had a beer to go with it. Well, since I can't have any alcohol whilst working, I damn well can do that when I step in here. 

The hella vegan burrito is still HELLA TASTY. 

I've only had burritos from Curry Up Now so I can't really comment on everything else. Still, they're HELLA good.
author: Susy C.

description: You should try this ..., i never knew they had so many options. Don't forget to try ' deconstructed samosa' with rice bowl. Add paneer to it.
author: Anudeep D.

description:
I used to like eating here during the Treasure Island Flea, but this may be my last time eating from this company for a few reasons.  The first reason is that the people working the food truck at the flea seem to not put the amount of care into the food as they used too by cooking the Chicken Tikka Masala separately from the garbanzo beans (they used to cook them together.). Instead they'll give you the Chicken Tikka Masala with a side of vegetarian curry then pass it off as something they have done for a long time.  Second the vegetarian curry/garbanzo beans they did give me were stone cold...  Actually the only hot part of my plate was the Chicken Tikka Masala everything else was cold.
Other than that the Chicken Tikka Masala tasted good, and the vegetarian/garbanzo bean curry tasted not so good.
author: Lance C.

description: I would love to "love" it but today's experience at Ft Mason was terrible. Ordered a lamb burrito (+ $1 for lamb) and had 2 VERY small pieces of lamb, was mostly only rice, bland, and very dry. No value in what they serve, $11 for a rice/potato wrap was a joke. This is my 2nd experience w/ them and will avoid in the future. Sorry guys
author: David C.

description: I dropped by here after always seeing this food truck outside of the Target today. It usually has a huge line, but I came right when they opened and ordered my food. I got their special of the day which was Butter Chicken Burrito. It took about 5 minutes and I got my food and brought it back to work. On a side note the lady was very nice and welcoming who took my order. I enjoyed the burrito quite a bit! It has some nice spices to it! I was not expecting it to be so flavorful (might be a tad spicy for people who don't like spicy) and I scarfed it up quickly. The burrito is packed and it felt like a small baby when I held it back into work. Overall, solid spot albeit a bit pricey, but it's kind of expected for food truck spots. Definitely recommend the Butter Chicken, but the Masala is definitely going to be the next one I jump on!
author: James R.

description:
Paneer Tikka Masala Bowl  - pretty good! I recommend it

Destructed Samosa with Paneer - pretty good! I recommend it
author: Hiral P.

description:
The chicken kathi roll blew me away.  It was one of the best things I've eaten in a long time.  I ordered spicy & gluten free, & it was straight up friggin delicious.  

So delicious, in fact, that I scarfed it down in my car...
while I was driving...
on the freeway.
I don't advocate doing this, but I couldn't stop.

There's always a line at lunch rush, so try & go early.  These guys are doing Indian street food w a twist, & they're doing it well.  Deconstructed samosas, sexy fries, naughty naan?  Ingenious.

Their sauces are delicious.  I can't vouch for anything other than the kathi roll or chicken tika masala burrito; but the sauces are awesome & authentic.  

They give my mom, my granny, & my aunties a run for their money.

5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
They suck at delivery. 

Food often comes with its container squashed like someone stepped on them.
author: D Z.

description:
Last Friday, a coworker of mine was going to Curry up now and offered to pick up food for anyone that wanted something. Of course I took the opportunity to ask for a Chicken tikka masala burrito, spicy please?! (No beans though since I don't like beans in my burritos.) When it arrived, I couldn't wait to dig in! The last time I got the burrito was from the truck at OtG: Upper Haight and I loved it!

I decided to open the burrito since I wasn't sure if I wanted to eat the whole thing. The first bite was still as amazing as I remember! The tikka masala sauce was spicy and comforting. The rice and chicken were coated well in it. I loved that there was a good amount of sauce! But as I kept eating the burrito, I noticed there wasn't much chicken in it. In fact, it only had 3-4 pieces of chicken in the whole burrito! I love rice with tikka masala sauce, but it's a chicken tikka masala burrito! I expected more chicken! 

Hence the 3 stars. For $8.50, there should have been more protein in the burrito. I thought it may have just been mine, but the two other coworkers that had the same burrito didn't get much chicken either. :(
author: Elena N.

description:
Went to the Truck Stop on mission street near Fremont street and it was super fast service at 1:30 pm

Mango lassi, as always was very good

The Tikka masala Spicy chicken burrito was really good.  A bit too spicy for me but everyone else loved it

I tried the naan with chicken tikka  masala  and carmelized onions and it was okay, kinda gooey, so won't order that again.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Decent Indian food truck in the financial district. Is a bit pricy for the quality of food they serve. 
I ordered the naked naan with chicken tikka. 

Since this is my first time, i can't comment on the quality of other items but the naan was pretty average. And the chicken tikka was sub par. And note they use chicken tikka (as an option) in ai their items.
author: Atanu R.

description:
I asked if they have whole wheat tortillas today and was told yes.  I ordered a chicken burrito with a whole wheat tortilla.  I got my order, opened the burrito to make sure, and it looked like a white tortilla to me.  I showed them and asked if it was a whole wheat tortilla.  They said yes, so, I, being in the time crunch I was in, decided to take their word for it.  When I fully opened the burrito a few minutes later, I confirmed it was a white tortilla.  Why did they lie?  To avoid the wasted burrito?  It seems the bigger they get, the worse they get.  I just recently discovered it was Curry Up Now that acquired the Tava that closed down.

As far as the food, it was good, but not as good as I remember it.

Also, please fix the menu.  "Flour or wheat tortilla" makes no sense; they are both flour tortillas and they are both wheat tortillas.  The options should be white or whole wheat.

I won't be going back to the truck, but I'd give the Valencia Street location another try.  The B&M location is nice because they offer both a brown rice and whole wheat tortilla option.
author: Nader Z.

description: Curry up now is very very good! The food is well prepared and the service is quite fast. This chain of food is very delicious and it's definitely one of my favorites here since I moved from Taiwan.
author: Xiang P.

description:
TLDR - great truck/lunch option; flavorful, filling Indian fusion for a good price

I used to see this truck all the time parked on Bush St back when I was working in FiDi and never got around to trying it despite all the good things I had heard about the chicken tikka masala burrito. Fortunately, they're also at Friday's Off The Grid at Civic Center and SOMA StrEat Park by my new work, so when I stopped by OTG for lunch, I decided I finally had to try this truck.

The menu is basically all Indian fusion (like burritos, bowls, fries, naan sandwiches). Obviously not amazing Indian food, but for Indian fusion and for a truck, it's pretty damn good. Not too pricey either and the portion size is reasonable. It's super quick too; my order was ready in less than 5 minutes.

I ordered the CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA BOWL ($8.50) instead of the popular burrito because I wasn't really feeling a tortilla that day. Plus, a bowl felt less messy to eat. I LOVE spicy food so I ordered mine spicy, which they describe as "pretty darn hot" on the menu. I was worried I wouldn't find their "spicy" to be remotely spicy at all because that tends to happen to me at a lot of places, but they don't kid around! I still would've liked it a little spicier, but it had a pretty good kick to it. The chicken was cooked well and the tikka masala was very flavorful. The rice was a little inconsistent though - some parts were mushy, some were overcooked and some were perfect - but still tasted good mixed with the tikka masala.
author: Jessie L.

description: Super rude order taker at the treasure island flea today. Now I know what you're the only food truck with no line.
author: ipvcake i.

description:
Enjoyed a chicken tikka burrito ($8.50) at Pleasanton OTG on a sunny Sunday afternoon. 

The guy that took my order was friendly and answered a couple of my questions regarding the menu. I ordered the burrito and within a few minutes it was handed to me in a brown paper bag. 

It was a good size and the ingredients of rice, chicken, garbanzo beans and sauce was perfect. The double wrap job in foil was nice so that helped against leakage. Don't ask me but I still managed to make a mess as if a 3 year old was chowing down. It sure was delicious!
author: Amber S.

description:
Bottom line: Made me want to curry up never. 

Ordered the tikka masala burrito, Tau the dude (A giant samosa) and beef tacos from this place (I was sharing with another friend). I came away very underwhelmed. This place very obviously doesn't emphasize the details. The burrito had whole chunks of potato wrapped inside of it, which was a huge distraction whenever you got a mouthful of bland potato that detracted from its overall seasoning, which was quite good. However, even the quality of the seasoning became a negative aspect, as it is strong and tasteful enough that by the time you're halfway through the burrito, you're already sick of it. 

The protein for the beef tacos was a mushy mess that tasted like 7-11 taquitos. 

The Tau, the Dude was the best dish I ordered. A very crispy samosa shell along with a great dipping sauce and filling. Please note that it contains a whole egg, smack dab in the middle. I found that quite amusing.  

I do have to admit that you get what you pay for. Curry Up now is quite cheap, so that's a plus.
author: Matthew L.

description:
They've already done the pun for me. 

One of those things where I feel like I have abandoned all hope of tradition and disparate national cuisines and identities. Obviously my Sushiritto review is just waiting to be written. 

That being said, gosh darn I love this. Just put sauce in a wrapper. You kind of just slurp up the curry from the naan-y/tortilla container that you can also eat. Which looks slightly better than licking the plate at the buffet. 

Pro tip: Anything more than Medium spicy might cause you to lose sensation in your face and eventually hit the Tums. Don't get too cocky just because the name has a pun in it.
author: Maya L.

description:
Greasy, carb-loaded (fusion) Indian street food. That's Curry Up Now for you.

Yelpers rave about the Chicken Tikka Masala (CTM) burrito, so I had to try one for myself. It's definitely worth $8.50 because the burrito is so HUGE that I can split it into two separate meals. Majority of the burrito contained rice, but I felt like there was still a good amount of chicken, so I didn't feel ripped off. The chicken was dry, but it was covered in a spicy, flavorful sauce that had just the right amount of heat.

The Kathi Roll with beef is a greasy greasy greasy mess! It's so damn oily that the oil leaked through the foil (which poorly wrapped the roll), soaking the paper bag and leaving a stain on my jeans that I can't remove. The beef was flavorful and juicy, and there were onions for some crunch. The ingredients were rolled up in an unevenly-distributed egg-washed flat bread that got soggy quickly. Overall, the kathi roll wasn't worth $6.50.

The Sexy Fries are oily as well, but not as bad as the kathi roll. For $8.50, you get sweet potato waffle fries topped with choice of meat, cheese, and onions. I opted for the chicken, which was disappointingly dry. The fries also got soggy pretty quickly.

If you can't handle spicy, skip Curry Up Now. Even their "mild" options have a kick to it. The only thing I highly recommend from this food truck is the CTM burrito. Other things have been a disappointment.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
Went to the food truck last week, oh man was it bomb!!

I had read about the dangerous level of heat that the Chicken Tikka Massala burrito offered, to which I yawned and rolled my eyes, as I live for spicy food. But ladies and germs, hold onto your tongues! This amount of heat was amazing! It's the building type, where it gets hotter and hotter the more you devour your delicious burrito. 

Chicken was oh-so tender, rice was perfectly seasoned, naan was soft and slightly charred, mmm mmm goooooood. Get there, people!
author: Crystal C.

description:
The food is most definitely FIVE stars. I give only four because if you order this food for delivery by ANY of the food delivery order places, you will not get something right. I always ask for hot sauce on the side, because you know you need that ghost pepper goodness with a paneer burrito or bowl. But no, they can NOT be bothered to ever include it, no matter how much you beg and plead by typing in the directions. I have even called them and asked them to include the sauce AFTER I placed the online order, was assured the sauce would be included, and had them forget it. This has happened countless times. 

So now they have a food truck outside my work. Boom bam, my sauce problems are all done. I just have to ask them and I make sure it is included. No more will I order the food for delivery though. If you are not adding anything special, or asking them to leave off an ingredient, go for it, order that delivery. If you want one single change, don't bank on them getting it right. 

But now the good stuff: One of the very BEST samosas of all the Indian food joints in the city. I mean that, and that is saying something. Perfectly cooked, just the right amount of crispiness. The tamarind chutney is really good. 

The paneer is super good. The Hella Vegan is my go-to, it is so beyond delicious! Even if you are not vegan, it's truly the best of all worlds, with a samosa chopped up with beans and rice, and chutneys and pico (I usually leave those out and opt for the ghost pepper hot sauce instead). 

The snack menu is pretty spectacular too. 

Pro Tip: when ordering with friends, order several snacks instead of just main dishes.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Curry Up Now is still my most favorite food truck/Indian food restaurant in the financial district. I've eaten everything off their menu, but my go-to is the chicken tikka burrito (surprise, surprise).  

Don't let the long line deter you! The line goes by quick and the food comes out even quicker. Also, A+ for the quick service. Gotta get that line moving! 

My stomach is always full and my wallet is pretty happy whenever I come here for lunch. 

P.S. They have "desi hot" option in case you want your food to be extremely spicy! I can handle it though ;P
author: Kitty K.

description:
High notes are: CTM, sexy fries and goat sweat.

The first time I encountered curry up now was at Outside lands 2015. It's hard to judge food when you're intoxicated and you've been walking for hours; at that point everything tastes good.

So this time I was more clear headed. I'm so glad too because I bought three things just to try the variety in their menu.

The CTM (chicken tikka masala) burrito was juicy and dripping with curry. I was expecting a lack of chicken and mostly potatoes but to my surprise there several pieces of cluck cluck.

The sexy fries are called sexy fries because of the "o" face you make while eating them. I recommend getting them over lamb if they have it available.

Speaking of baahhhhhhdass food. The goat sweat (Monday special only), was an interesting blend of bone in goat meat and traditional Indian spices. Not too sure what else was in there, maybe potatoes.

They also offer traditional mango lassee but I was too full to order.

All in all I will back here again, as this is the most popular food truck in the food truck lunch circle on 2nd and Folsom.
author: James T.

description: The deconstructed samosa is to die for!! I definitely didn't need to add paneer and chicken to it - I'm sure it would have been more than enough food by itself but perhaps it's because I also got a mango lassi (which was also excellent). Either way,  solid choice and two thumbs up!! Also, arrive at 11.30am to be the first in line!!
author: Pia K.

description: I was a little skeptical when I heard of curry burritos, but they do it right. Perfectly balanced between all the ingredients, but they tend to run on the spicy side. I've had the fried ravioli (I must've missed the "fried" part) but it was definitely interesting. Also, be mindful of the time between ordering the criss-cut fries and when you're eating them as they tend to get a little soggy
author: Sara F.

description:
There's a hurly-burly vibe in this place that could feel like you've landed on the streets of Kolkata, but no, you're in a typically frantic hipster haven in the Mission (photo: http://bit.ly/1aMdEv8). The target customers appear to be twenty-somethings with lopsided haircuts. I don't know how I managed to pass under the radar, but Jamie W. and I decided to take a detour in here to give it a try. I've eaten the Tikka Masala Burrito off the food truck on Bush and liked it enough to be curious about the popularity of this place. Jamie was willing to forgo Alhamra to come here, no small feat. The menu was fairly undecipherable at twenty paces with graphics that make it more challenging to read than an eye exam at the DMV.

Jamie surprisingly got all Hindu on me and ordered the $11 Eight Item Thali Platter, probably the most traditionally Indian dish on the menu. On a prison cafeteria tray was served parantha, garbanzo beans, pickles, papadum, rice and salad. He got two entrees to complete the tray, and Jamie selected the Chicken Tikka Masala and the Beef M.E.A.T. Stew. It was quite a potpourri of distinct flavors, a bit on the hit-and-miss side but exemplary in execution for a place fashioned after a street food cart. My order was more aligned with the food truck I knew as I started with the $11 Naughty Naan, which starts with a smaller piece of naan and tops it with tikka masala, cheese, greens, onions, shaved jalapeños and chunks of lamb (photo: http://bit.ly/147deAx).

Sure, it was delicious, but I doubt I would find something like this on the outskirts of Jodhpur. It was way too San Francisco-style gourmet to be found in a knapsnak carried by a camel in the desert. Even further afield from Rajasthan are the $8 Sexy Fries, a half-order of sweet potato fries dressed with cheese and onions and topped by, believe it or not, Pork Belly (photo: http://bit.ly/13hwg0O). Decadently delicious like an upscale South Asian version of chili cheese fries. Tables look randomly placed in the expansive space, so if you don't mind an inadvertent elbow when someone walks past you, then you shouldn't have a problem. By the way, this is the only one of their current locations that offers all-day weekend breakfast specials from different parts of India. That would make for a worthwhile return visit.

FOOD - 4 stars...Indian street food with a hipster twist...pork belly and lamb toppings get a thumbs up from me
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a bit chaotic
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...surprisingly orderly in a disorderly space
TOTAL - 4 stars...as long as the food is good, I don't care as much about the chaos
author: Ed U.

description: Really nice way of mashing up east with the west. One of the better Indian fusion places
author: Prasanth V.

description:
Very large servings!  I got the Chicken Tikka Masala bowl for $8.50 and was only able to eat a little more than half of what they gave me.  The recycled paper box was not sufficient to hold all the sauce and I kept worrying that I will spill them on my shirt.  Definitely get  naan with it (sold separately) to make sure that you don't waste that curry goodness!

They didn't ask me for spiciness level and what they gave me had plenty of kick!  Over all pleased with this truck and will check out their other offerings next time.
author: Amihan M.

description:
The only thing I didn't like was that they put whole baby potatoes in my lamb burrito. We're talking larger than bite-sized potatoes just thrown into my burrito. I was a little taken back by the fact that they couldn't cut the potatoes up to make it less overwhelming. I literally took out 4-5 whole potatoes from my burrito because it was too much and even a little undercooked for my taste.

However, flavor and taste-wise, this truck is great. I've never been dissatisfied of their ability to highlight real Indian spices. I love that they have goat and lamb--both essentials! Of course I think its slightly overpriced, but your also paying for convenience and quality. I'm not a frequent visitor, but I will most likely visit again.
author: Junel S.

description:
Don't expect it to be your tradition Indian food. I would call it Indian Fusion.  Curry Up Now offers menu items that are innovative and new. Expect to be amazed with dishes like Sexy Fries and Deconstructed Samosas.  

There was a week where all I would eat was Chicken Sexy Fries which was 
Chicken Tikka Masala over Crisscut Sweet Potato Fries ~$8, what a genius idea its like an Indian version of chili fries. The sweet and spicy flavor were a great combination.  I tried the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito which was a fun spin on your regular Mexican burrito very flavorful, it did not disappoint.  

Another favorite of mine was the Chicken Deconstructed Samosas ~ $6, which is not wrapped up in a fried pastry shell, the filling sits on top of the shell and overflows with spicy goodness. The base is comprised of mashed potatoes, and it's loaded with chickpeas, onions and other spices, chutneys and chopped tomatoes all this is a treat to your palette.  The flavors mix to give you a party in your mouth.  

Curry Up Now is one of my favorite food trucks! Great food at affordable prices.  I love it that they now use OrderAhead so I can use the app to place my order and not have to fall in line to claim my food.  Perfect!
author: Maria M.

description:
This place is right by where I work and I frequent it whenever the food at work is not good. Today was one such day and I ordered the chicken katti roll. I have ordered this a few times previously and never had a problem. The roll was so oily that the oil was literally dripping from my bag when I was holding it. It was so bad that when I went to Target next they gave me a bag to stop the oil from dripping all over their floor. I did not notice the oil dripping earlier otherwise I would have returned it and gotten a refund. 

Please be careful to check the bottom of your bag to make sure it's not swimming in oil before leaving the food truck. It was $20 down the drian as I bought 2 rolls one for me and another for my friend.
author: Pradeep J.

description:
This is my first review but second time to the Curry Up Now food truck.
It's ok but honestly I remembered why I hadn't been back for a long time.

There are questions and concerns....

I'm not Indian (so what do I know) but when I order Chicken Tikka Masala I think of chicken in a creamy sauce. Not here. It's tasty chicken but not creamy at all.

There is no flavor to the rice or it's very subtle so when you take a bite that is mainly rice it's like biting into steamed rice wrapped in a tortilla. A little bit boring...*in my best Paco di Bango voice* (BTW if you know who paco di bango is and heard his voice when you read it- we should probably be friends)

Lastly stewed chicken, garbanzo beans and rice all have similar "mushy-like" quality...why not throw a different texture in there. I suggest a cucumber spear and maybe cilantro.

That being said I ate the whole thing in about 10 min and my nose is running due to spiciness.
author: Edi B.

description: The burrito was quite flimsy. The desi hot option for the burrito was indeed extremely spicy. I was disappointed that the burrito contained a lot of rice but not much meat
author: James S.

description:
Got there around 11:45am, the line was very short. Got the chicken tikka masala bowl as recommended. One of the chicken pieces was really dry, but the masala flavor was decent. Very good chana masala on the side. 

In general, not a bad option for food truck, but if reviewed as Indian food, it's just meh.
author: June L.

description:
Curry up now really made the transition from a truck to a brick and mortar joint really well. They should really put one in Berkeley. It would do great if it were near campus.

Anyways, the chicken tikka masala burrito just works. When places try to do with with naan instead of just a tortilla, things feel forced. Naan can't really wrap a saucy thing well and you end up having a leaky wrap with perhaps too chewy bread. Just using a tortilla really fixes all these problems and Curry Up Now doesn't feel so beholden to their theme that they mind using the path of least resistance.
author: Misha T.

description: This is bad Indian food.  My date asked for saag paneer "extra spicy" so the cook poured half a bottle of hot sauce on top of it, which made it pretty much inedible.  I still have PTSD from my one bite of it.  The food was also served barely warm.  This restaurant is living off its name as a food truck.  As a stand-alone restaurant it is just plain lousy.  If you want good Indian food, don't eat at Curry Up Now.
author: Wendell L.

description:
The naan is the most attention-seeking, dressed up, warm/tingly on your tongue piece of flatbread I have ever met. 

There are some pickled peppers they use in their Cauliflower that is certainly not for the faint of heart. 

But very satisfying and not too salty.
author: Jenny L.

description:
7x7 100 Best Things To Eat In SF Before You Die 

#53 Tika Masala Burrito at Curry Up Now's Truck 

I am sorry to say their Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito is a huge miss for me.  I went to the Off the Grid in Marin and to my surprise Curry Up Now was there. I figure what a great opportunity for me to finally knock something off my list. 

I was cautiously excited because I normally am not a fan of fusion foods and two my sister in law told me she was not a fan.

Without going on a rant I will keep it short. The curry rice was way overpoweing, chicken was dry and I could not taste the Tikka Masala flavor. Honestly, I tried to keep going but by the time I got half way through I knew it was hopeless to continue. I really love Indian food so it hurts me even more to have to write such a negative review. 

Unfortunately, again 7x7 and I are at odds with one another

Overall Thoughts

I won't be trying the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito again. I would rather spend my money at The Architect's Kitchen and get me some delicious Fried Chicken and Donuts!
author: Eddie W.

description:
I think Curry Up Now is one of the best, if not *the* best, food truck in San Francisco. They had a much simpler menu the first time I visited a few years ago and I am really impressed with where they've taken the business.

My fav is the Deconstructed Samosa. What a friggin' masterpiece. It's hella royal. I thought I was the only one who mixed chutneys with my curries. Indian restaurants often serve it with papadum, but I find I find myself just smothering it on my other food. Well, that's kind of what they did here. Well that's only part of it. There's a lot of other things going on in here and I suggest you try it

Also last time I went here I felt a bit daring and ordered spicy. The guy asked if I had spicy before and when I said I hadn't he said he'll put it on the side for me. Good gesture. I ended up only putting half of it in and it was definitely spicy enough for me.
author: Andrew D.

description:
review is for Curry Up Now food truck on Bush Street 
I ordered my food via Order Ahead and went 3 mins after the food should have been ready. The White guy with gel spike hair said they dont support 'order ahead' only square from their website. He was not even apologetic or a bit surprised. When I suggested he should because I did not want to wait for my food, he shrugged his shoulders and said 'Why? we dont support Order Ahead. Tell me what your order is I will prepare it now' He made a big show of writing my order from the order ahead confirmation email and proceeded to prepare the food. 

When I tried to confirm if the food was 'desihot' the woman in the truck shoved 2 more sauces in my face. 'I have put it in but here it is for you'

The only saving grace was the cook guy who offered me a lassi on him to make up for this experience.

I am still waiting for my apology, if you dont support order ahead dont take money for online orders. You want to keep the money, give a time but not apologize when food is not ready. 

In my opinion the first ingredient that needs to be served is RESPECT and I found that to be severly lacking.
author: Heena K.

description: Got the butter chicken burrito and it tasted nothing like butter chicken. Huge let down. It was mostly rice too. It tasted good but I was lookin for that delicious butter chicken flavor. I would not get again
author: Shana K.

description:
What a great food truck!  

The line was superrrrr long but well worth the wait! 

We ordered the sexy fries...a bed of fries covered with chicken tikka masala and cheese. To die! 

Can't wait to check out the other items on this truck!
author: Morgan F.

description:
Yummy.

Sexy fries with chicken tikka masala. 

I said I want it spicy, and he said, "Are you sure?" I have to admit that as I nodded at him, I felt a little bit of doubt. AM I sure? What if it's too spicy for me? What if it's too spicy for my friend and I end up feeling like a jerk?

It was barely spicy. Next time I think I could go for the one that claims to make people cry.

My friend said, "I think this might be the best thing I've ever eaten." I don't know if I'd go that far, but it was pretty damn good, and better than anything I can make at home.

Why must you be so far away? 

The fries were like $9, plus whatever amount I end up spending on transportation to go all the way to Berkeley for these fries between now and the next Sacto Mofo. 

The fries also went really well with the Stella I was drinking. 

I was a little confused by the lack of curry. For a place that is called Curry Up Now, shouldn't there be, like... curry dishes? I would think of this more as Indian-American fusion than Indian street food.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I loved the tikka burrito, really yummy!  Only things I would change is I would actually have liked more rice and a tad less sauce in mine because it was super gloppy and the service when I went was not that friendly.  Not horrible but the guy just seemed like he was bored and not that happy to see my face.
author: Emma H.

description: I had the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito desi hot for lunch and holy shit the desi hot is spicy. Nonetheless, the burrito tasted great with flavorful Tikka masala inside (with garbanzo brand as well). Overall it was pretty filling, especially taking into consideration other food truck portions/value.
author: Eric F.

description: I have only been here once but the chicken kathi roll was amazing! It had the right amount of spice and flavor. It is a little messy but feels worth it.  I don't go to a lot of food trucks but this one made me want to come back. I also tried the mango lassi drink which hit the spot and cut through the spice of the food. It is a fairly sweet drink but good on a hot day.  Price is pretty reasonable.  So curry up and get there!
author: Jennifer C.

description: This review is just for their mint ginger lemonade. Worst thing ever. Literally tasted like hot and spicy curry.  Not refreshing at all.  Had my boyfriend try it to see if my taste buds were off and he spit it out. 3.25 for 12 Oz of that? No thanks.
author: mackenzie e.

description:
Tried this at Off the Grid, where they are normally not at!

They really are normally at the financial district as I saw them again at Civic Center for the World Cup final.

Chicken Marsala & Mango Yassi was delicious. It had a good kick of different spices. Be careful eating chicken marsala burrito as it is freshly made and anyone with some common sense would wait a lil before biting into it or it burn your mouth. 

Lines are long, why? cause they know the food is good. Up to you if you want to wait.
author: Corie L.

description:
It took me a while but I finally got to try this stuff!

Curry Up Now was stationed at SFSU this week so I decided to check it out. Initially, I wanted a pork belly kathi roll but they didn't have pork belly. Damn.

I decided to get the chicken tikka masala burrito instead. I saw that they had mango lassi cups on display underneath the window so I got one of those too. $8 and $3 respectively.

The chicken tikka masala burrito was BOMB. So good. Very flavorful and juicy. The sauce was great, the rice was great, and the chicken was succulent tasty. I didn't realize that the burritos were pre-made so when they called my order, it took me a while to realize that it was me. Seriously took like a minute or something.

The mango lassi is worth getting. Admittedly kind of pricey, but you never see mango lassis for less than $3. This one tastes very fresh. Rich, refreshing, and goes really well with the food I ordered.

I would go back.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Woo hoo, burrito all the things. The truck has a pretty decent selection of burritos, that said of all the times I've been here, I've never gotten anything other than the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito. Don't forget to ask for some ghost chilli sauce if you are feelin up to the spice, or alternatively get some tamarin sauce if you want to enjoy your afternoon. 

Definitely give this truck a try if you are in the FiDi, just be prepared, as there is a good possibility of a pretty decent sized line.
author: David C.

description:
They had me at chicken tikka masala burrito and sexy fries. They really are sexy ladies and gents!

The food truck and their restaurant location definitely don't cut corners when it comes to items on their menu! I've been to both and I have to say, I was pretty impressed the food truck tasted just as good as the restaurant. 

My only complaint - the food gets a little sloppy and messy. Don't try and wear a white dress shirt, the day you opt to eat here.
author: Sonal P.

description:
All you need to know is deconstructed samosa. Just let that term sit with you. Deconstructed. Not inside out, not backwards. Deconstructed.

One star docked for long-term health concerns.
author: Sahil P.

description:
3.5.  Love how you can always find this truck here.  No surprises or ambiguity. 

Menu is unique with cool names like sexy fries.  Got the chicken tikka masala burrito.. Or ctm burrito to sound cool.  Burrito was saucy with basmati rice, cubes of chicken, and garbanzo beans.  They didn't ask me what spice level I wanted, so I think it's their norm of med spicy (which was not spicy at all.. Maybe a tiny kick but not spicy).  It was a very filling and carby burrito for $8.50.  Definitely felt full and lazy afterwards.  It needed something to brghten up all the flavors....maybe some sort of chutney will do....just my opinion.

Passed on getting their sexy fries; devouring a burrito and fries will definitely not make one sexy.
author: Linda T.

description:
Let me say this first - I LOVE Curry Up Now. I've been going for years (and bringing all my friends) to the Palo Alto and Valencia St locations. The burrito I had today at this location was really really really *really* bad.

Firstly, it was so badly wrapped that when I opened the foil, masala sauce was everywhere, on everything. I tried picking up the burrito and it was squishing around in my hands - I couldn't even get a hold of it. Not pleasant. Then the masala sauce, which I'm used to being so amazing and flavorful, was watery, thin, and bland. I had to scoop some of the rice out because it was also watery and bland, no salt even. And there were hardly any garbanzo beans - maybe 5 or 10 beans in the whole thing.

I have a hard time believing this is the same chain I've been going to for so long. Really unimpressed with how variable the quality is if this is what sells at this location.  :(
author: Kate F.

description:
This is one of those food trucks that always has a line, so best to hit this one up at 11-11:30am or 1pm.

The sexy fries were smothered with their Indian sauce, and I found words other than "sexy" coming to mind as I made a dent in the contents of my little brown box.

The tikki masala burrito is what I'd come back for, but with the awareness that its MESSY. I didn't realize how many napkins I'd need (this is coming from a 99.9% spill-free diner).  Perhaps a bowl would be the way to go. Chicken was all high quality (no weird fatty pieces to ruin a bite) and the sauce was rich and filling but not so heavy that a food coma inevitably follows.

Bonus: my gluten-free colleague had a couple of clearly labeled options to try.

In summary: Get the tikki masala burrito/bowl!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Beware! The menu online differs from the food truck! BIG DISAPPOINTMENT!

I ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala, why? because that's basically all they had at the truck! You order the burrito or Kathi Roll, but that roll looked too small for $6.50.  But I will be back for the burrito, only because it keeps me full, thanks to all the carbs and fat! Long lines, so come early!!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I got the naughty naan with chicken tikka masala for $10 and a mango lassi for $3. Basically it was chicken tikka masala on top of naan. I really liked their naan! It was crunchy on the bottom yet soft on the top so it was really fun to eat. The actual chicken tikka masala was pretty good but not as good as the one I get from House of Curries in Berkeley. The one at House of Curries is a lot creamier and has a lot more sauce. The one here though did have a lot of cheese which was a huge plus (even though I'm lactose intolerant I loved the cheese). Also, the mango lassi was a bit sour and not as sweet as I'm used to so it was just all right. I will definitely be back to try their fries!
author: Sarah K.

description:
It is no secret that I am a burrito fanatic. My second most frequently need food fix happens to be Indian. So, you can imagine just how excited I was to find out about the amazing hybrid that is the curry burrito sold by the creative--nay, genius--minds at Curry Up Now. 

I actually don't usually get chicken tikka masala when I go to Indian restaurants because I have to be a rebel, so it's been a while since I've tasted the sweeter and creamier curry that is CTM. For me, the burrito was the perfect spicy-ness level, enough to make one pause and let the flavors simmer on one's tongue between bites, but not enough to hinder the eating process. There were sizable onion pieces in the mix as well. 

Since Eat Real items had to be $5 or less, I believe they downsized their burrito a bit, but the miniature version actually served to satiate me comfortably without the usual overstuffed post-burrito feeling. If you like Indian, or any sort of wraps really, definitely hunt this truck down!
author: Amy G.

description:
Tasty and Hot Indian Food. Tried different items in Menu and never got disappointed.
Cons -
Only Complain - Don't try Mango Lassi here it is worst.
author: Praveen A.

description:
My coworker and I placed an order online and were very careful about picking the location. When we got to the truck they said our order probably went somewhere else and asked us what we wanted.

We re-ordered our items. I asked for Chicken Tikka Masala (nowhere did I say I wanted it spicy).

They gave me the Spicy version which I did NOT order and honestly I love spice and all, but this is overly spicy which is why I did not order it. Super disappointed about this. I told the lady at the truck I didn't order the spicy version and she just ignored me.
author: Tanya S.

description: It tasted like Mexican food with a few Indian spices thrown in. Hands down the worst Thali I've ever had and I feel sick after eating it.
author: Eater S.

description:
TL; DR version: I stopped by this food truck today, and the food was pure hell. Heck, if I was a suing man, I'd be suing them for damages.

So here's what happened. We ordered 2 "hella vegan" burritos. They have 3 levels of spices: "medium" (the default), "spicy" (which I guess is spicier), and the third, "desi ('they-see') spicy" which has a sauce made of ghost peppers and trinidad scorpio (sic) peppers.

Now, i've tasted ghost pepper sauces; heck, I have Dave's Ghost Pepper sauce at home. It is *NOT* something to be trifled with; I avoid it unless I'm really, REALLY looking for pain. So, when ordering, I told the dude: "I want it spicy, but NOT "desi" spicy! Are we clear?" I must've repeated this 3 times, and he made sure that he understood it. In fact, he went so far as to say "desi spicy", and then corrected himself.

We take our HV burritos and head out to find a nice place to sit. First of all: the burritos are pre-made. So if you want to change the spiciness or alter an ingredient, they have to unwrap it, make the change, and wrap it back up. Anyone who has messed with a burrito knows that doing this, the end result is not the same. So the burritos we got were misshapen and loose. But never mind; a delicious Indian lunch beckoned. Or so i thought.

After a few bites, I realized that the spice level was a bit too much. But I had explicitly told them not to make it "desi spicy", right? Repeatedly. So they couldn't have screwed it up; maybe the heat was just passing. 

Now, anyone who has had ghost pepper (or the hotter Trinidad Scorpion) knows that it doesn't burn you immediately, but the heat builds up; unlike, say, a habanero or a jalapeno, where you feel the heat immediately. And once the ghost pepper gets going, nothing can help you because it's inside you, burning its way out. It's like eating too much of a pot brownie (and it will make you hallucinate too).

But coming back to my tale. As I was finishing the burrito,  and as the heat continued to build up, it dawned on me that they had, in fact, given me the "desi hot" version. Fucking hell. Soon I was hyper-ventilating, and pacing back and forth as the fire radiated out from my belly, making me sweat like crazy. After dowsing it with water and Odwalla drinks, I was able to come back to my senses.

Here's the thing: most other places will warn you if they're about to unleash this much carnage on your innards. But this place? No sir! What a bunch of idiots.  If they don't even know how to handle something so dangerous as ghost pepper sauce, how the heck are they in the food business??
author: A J.

description: curry up now is fire best spot in sf for indian street food , great portions and dope atmosphere
author: Jeff M.

description:
I used to work at 225 Bush and I would frequent Curry Up Now pretty often! I am a huge fan of their chicken tikka masala bowl! Think Chipotle but Indian fusion. 

Pro-tip: you can order online and then you don't have to wait in line - you just walk right up to the counter to pick up your food. Definitely helpful as it tends to get busy during lunchtime!
author: Teresa C.

description:
I went to the Sacramento Pacific Rim Street Festival specifically for this truck.  Since SacMoFo is always crawling with line-cutting vultureous fatties who gobble up the truck's entire food supply, I decided to go the less crowded route and track this truck down alone.

In sha'Allah!  God willed me to eat here!  Out of everything I've tried at the festival, C.u.N. was THE BEST.  Chicken tikki masala burrito and potato Samosa were bomb.nom!

The burrito was the size of a juicehead's arm and samosa, the size of his overgrown ego.  They didn't ask how spicy we wanted it, but after eating half of it, my tastebuds started to cry out of my nose.  I assume they assumed Asians can eat spicy.  Samosa was good.. flaky, soft potatoes inside, but the sweet chutney sauce for it was even mooore so delicious that I would've drank it if I hadn't already used it all up.  The burrito was so damn bomb, I considered buying extra to-go and storing the stash in my nuthole for future munching.

There isn't an overwhelming smell of onion/ spices that you would normally get from eating in an Indian restaurant.  This is the best smelling CuNt ever!  Oops I mean CuN, typo..  So curry your butt up and get over here!
author: Regina N.

description:
Everything tasted okay until I made it halfway through my burrito and found a huge long piece of hair.

Gross.

I was already at the office so couldn't go back and complain.

I think hairnets should be required during food preparation.

Picture of said hair:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/curry-up-now-san-francisco?select=f0vR4SNGmecwhVG9vAqiiA#f0vR4SNGmecwhVG9vAqiiA
author: Jean K.

description:
SHORT: Terribly bland, watery food, several friends got sick at different times, not worth wait.

LONG(ish):
I am a huge fan of Indain food. This truck was always parked outside of our building on Bush and always had a line, everyday for months. When the line didn't let up, we finally decided to give it a try. It was a horrible decision.

We both tried the Chicken Tikka Masala wrap and neither of us finished. The sauce was watery and orange but with a distinct lack of seasoning.  it was so watery that is basically dripped continuously if you held the burrito up. 

There was an enormous amount of rice and wrap, not much chicken at all. The chicken that was there was cut or shredded very thin. 

This is hands down the worst Indian food I have ever tried. I personally have never gotten ill from their food but many of my co-workers did. The guys in the truck were also very brisk and unfriendly. i get that you are stuck in a truck and there is a line of people but that doesn't mean you have to sacrifice courtesy.
author: Dana V.

description:
This is a review for their food truck catering.

My now-husband and I hired the Curry Up Now truck to do our wedding catering, and it was super-awesome-deliciously great!! They were already my favorite food truck (Hella Vegan Decon forever!!!), and they did not disappoint for a second. Their lovely staff added to the delight of the day, and our wedding guests could not stop talking about our Sexy Fries appetizers. And holy moly, fried cheesecake?!? It was all just superb. They were incredibly easy to work with, and so much less fussy (and way less expensive) than your average wedding catering. Five stars and two big thumbs up!!
author: Christin R.

description: If you're looking for a low protein option, their chicken tikka masala bowl without rice is great. They could do better on the paneer tikka.
author: Rish M.

description:
The Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito is SO EFFEN BOMB it had my mouth singing, "BOOM BOOM POWWWWWWWWWW"!!!

On Friday, 4.1.11, I was finally able to visit the Curry Up Now truck at Off The Grid - Civic Center. My co-worker and I arrived several minutes before the event started at 11:30 AM and luckily beat the lines. I ordered the much-hyped CTM Burrito ($7) and made it a Combo (Samosa and Mango Lassi) for an additional $4. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AjuUljBC7tCMxX5eiWlzMA?select=XjPo2w0UmoKbaCmGnoGidg 

CC's are accepted. Since the CTM Burrito is pre-made, it only took 2 minutes to get my order. 

When I received my order, the fragrant curry aroma started to permeate through the brown bag and I couldn't wait to get back to the office so I can devour my meal.

CTM BURRITO:
THE BEST AND MOST FLAVORUFL BURITTO I'VE EVER HAD!!! I'm not a huge fan of fusion cuisine because the authenticity of flavors seem to be water-downed in order appeal to the general public, but NOT in this case... 

Wrapped in a soft tortilla, the chicken tikka masala was BURSTING with rich, bold flavors and spices! The tikka masala sauce was rich, creamy, tangy and savory with a hint of exotic sweetness from the coconut milk. The earthy spices of tumeric, coriander, cumin and cardamom really shined through and gave a great subtle punch while the cayenne pepper added enough heat to make my cheeks blush. The chunks of tender chicken (a tad dry though) and perfectly al-dente rice soaked and married with the tikka masala sauce making each bite of the CTM burrito extremely flavorful. The chana (chick peas) were tender, yet slightly crisp which gave the burrito a nice texture contrast. Each bite tantalized every one of my taste buds and sent me on a subliminal bliss. *Eyes roll back in the head*

Fyi, I forgot to order my burrito "spicy", but the regular gave this spicy food lover the right amount of fiery heat to set my mouth on a subtle fire. 

The burrito was generously filled with the chicken tikka masala and rice so I was only able to eat half of the burrito before becoming stuffed. When I ate the remaining half for dinner 6 hours later, it held up very well as the tortilla was not soggy. 

SAMOSA:
Although the skin was crunchy and crisp, I didn't care too much for the potato filling as it was bland and lacked the prominent curry spices. 

MANGO LASSI:
Thick, rich, creamy, sweet and tart, the yogurt and milk in Mango Lassi really help to sooth the heat from the burrito. However, it wasn't iced enough so it was almost lukewarm. 

I always end up disappointed with hyped up places, but Curry Up Now's CTM Burrito totally lived up to its hype and is now my FAVORITE food truck! There are very few life-changing foods in my book but the CTM burrito wins a place in mine and is definitely worthy to be on the 7x7 List. So Curry Up Now and send your mouth on a BOOM BOOM POW adventure!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: I got the chicken tikka masala bowl. I thought the long-grained basmati rice was fragrant and cooked perfectly. The various sauces were tasty, but the protein was definitely an afterthought. The chicken was tender but wasn't flavorful on its own and relied on the sauces to carry the weight. I don't think it was that special, but decent.
author: Jin C.

description:
In lieu of a brick & mortar lunch spot, I suggested checking out the 'food pod' set up in South San Francisco Tuesday afternoon. Pods are 2-3 food trucks set up on set days, during set hours (11am-2pm, in this case) to feed employees in the area. As we drove up to the Centennial Towers, I announced, 'you know we're headed into someone's job just to eat, right?!' 

Technically, it's the outdoor parking lot of someone's job, but still...the lengths I'll go to avoid traditional restaurant settings has reached epic proportions lately. Our warmish weather has made me weary of silverware, table cloths, & waiters. This parking lot was exactly what I was looking for! The intense 1pm sunshine made me thankful for my Neutrogena SPF 45. Benches served as our table. 

Curious, but hesitant, I strolled up to Curry Up Now. I'd never even taken a peek at their menu, let alone sampled their goods. I ordered sexy fries ($8.) Love the name! Sweet potato criss-cut fries topped with white meat chicken tikka masala & white onions. Slightly tart, very fragrant, spicy...fairly enjoyable, but since I rarely gravitate towards these flavors, I could only eat 4 or 5 bites. Even though the fries were 4-stars good, I'm only rating the truck 3 stars because I'm not an Indian food fan & would probably not eat from here again. $8 for something I only want a few bites of is too steep a price... if they offered half orders, I'd reconsider. 

Glad I finally tried this truck. Highly recommended for those looking for a Mexico-meets-India pairing, as the menu features Indian fare wrapped in tortillas!
author: Fancypants X.

description: Ordered the Thali Combo Platter, and it was really good! The Chana masala is perfect and I should have asked them to make it as desi hot. Would definitely go back to try their other food.
author: Avisha P.

description: Sadly, this truck has gone downhill. The burritos and portion sizes have shrunk and the prices have gone up. They were also out of cheese last time. It was fun while it lasted
author: Mike O.

description:
Delicious quick food. Don't forget to ask for the ghost chili.

CTM burrito is my favorite. I need to make myself try the other options.
author: Tori M.

description:
It took a few more trips, but I'm finally giving Curry Up Now their 5th star.  My last few meals from them have pretty much blown me away.

During one visit I had the Chicken Kathi Roll, which was pretty good, but it was pretty much overshadowed by the Paneer Tikka Masala Burrito which I had always enjoyed.

Then after lessons learned from my first experience, I had a Regular Spice Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito.  No fire in my mouth this time, but in turn I got to finally taste the Burrito and every bite was delicious.  It still had some spice to it, but that only enhanced the overall flavor.  It's really too bad that they don't have a Chicken and Paneer Tikka Masala Burrito.  That would so rock!

Today was when they hit their highest note so far when I had their "Almost Famous" Torta with Chicken and a side of Sweet Potato Fries (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw&select=20LLF81b6RWs81S0BcRw4g).  It was amazing!  Huge pieces of Marinated Chicken Breast, lettuce, tomato, and guacamole.  And then it comes with Sweet Potato Fries and you've got an awesome deal for $8.
