ANYWAYS,  I would probably rather try a new truck before coming here again. Would be interested in trying their other products though in the future.
author: Melissa C.

description: Ordered the deconstructed samosa with chicken and did not think it was anything special. The dish is served with garbanzo beans, chutneys, 4 mini samosas and a larger open-faced samosa on the bottom. Personally, I did not like the flavor of the curry and thought there was way too much potato and garbanzo beans in this dish. My friend ordered the same dish with paneer and said she liked it so might give that a try if I come back. Also, I can usually tolerate pretty spicy food but the medium spice level is the most I can handle here.
author: Nikitha R.

description:
Yum, Deconstructed Samosa!

I have not tried anything but this, and I've had it twice. With Paneer and Rice. I also ask for hot sauce and extra chutney, and get a couple cups of Raita. 

It comes in a small container, like the size of a box for a fast food hamburger. Fear Not, you'll be stuffed before you finish, and not at all guilty about what you've consumed. 

There are plenty of photos here of what I order. Find the Curry Up Now truck (Lucky for me, It's right down the street from my office!) and enjoy!

But, come early... that line get's a little crazy 'round noon!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
The vegan gluten-free burrito bowl tasted good, and was not overly salty.  

You can customize the level of spicyness for your meal: I got the middle level "spicy" and while it felt lacking in spicyness for me, I have a high tolerance for spicy food, so it probably was actually on par for most eater's expectations.
author: Wolfe S.

description:
Spectacular!  I've been going to their food trucks for years now, and was so excited to have a permanent location to near to me (my hopes for maintaining a healthy diet, however, makes me less excited....)

Been a couple times now and everything is DELICIOUS!  I love all the vegetarian options, and how cheap everything is.  Sometimes it doesn't look like a lot of food, but IT. IS. SO. FILLING.  I'll often eat there for a late lunch and the not even need dinner later that day, I'm so stuffed.  The sexy fries are deadly and the thali is delish, and that naan sandwich is insane.  Calorie heaven!!!!
author: Monica R.

description:
I was super disappointed with this truck.  They don't have a lot of options--they don't even have chai.  WTF?  Basically its basmati rice soaked in salty, oily curry and rolled up in a tortilla with a few garbanzo beans strewn about.  I was expecting some flavor!   Burritos have guacamole, salsa, etc., so I was expecting some condiments--raita, fresh diced tomato and cilantro, some mint sauce.  What a freaking boring experience.  And $8.50 for a tortilla with what amounts to a few tablespoons of rice and some paneer?  The flavor wasn't anything special.  My lassi wasn't good either.  Lassies should be refreshing and cooling.  Theirs was so thick it made me feel ill after drinking half of it.  I won't be waiting in that long line ever again...unless they bring something to the table that seems like it took some consideration to prepare.

Way hyped up.  My Fi-Di Indian Food quest continues....
author: Kandi K.

description:
My first food truck experience after starting my new job in the city and it's  awesome enough that I go there once a week. My favorite is the paneer tikka masala burrito, followed by the chicken tikka masala burrito. Spicy is actually spicy. I actually won a dare by finishing a spicy paneer burrito and it was a struggle, two containers of yogurt, two Pepsis and a Perrier later I managed to get it down. The awesome thing is that even with as spicy and painful as it was, the flavor was still great, it wasn't pain for pain's sake. The medium spicy should be just right for normal palates and you can get the hot sauce on the side if you want to kick things up a notch. 

I enjoy the lassis as well, though they border on too sweet for me. They do their job of toning down the spice very well though.
author: Andrew M.

description:
My husband and I had seen the truck for this and we were looking forward to trying this place. We finally did and we were honestly disappointed. The food tasted like it had been sitting for a while and then plated as we ordered, which I'm imagining it was. It'm usually ok with that, but it honestly tasted like left overs. We spent  about $40 for two of us and for a "fast food" type of place that seemed price especially since the quality was mediocre. 

Bottomline, I don't think my husband and I will be going back.
author: Dianne L.

description:
I'm a believer...  My Spicy Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito was hella spicy and totally off the hook, and the chicken this time around was totally tender!   It's a long wait to place your order and get that delish little brown paper bag full of love, but it's so hella worth it!

Yes, I overuse the word 'hella' when I'm extremely excited.  Sue me.
author: David O.

description: Their deconstructed samosas literally bring me to tears they're so good. I love the option of ordering online which gives me just enough time to make my way there on foot with my food waiting for me!
author: jerry s.

description:
Got there early and waited in line for 15 solid minutes at Off the Grid for their signature (curry) masala burrito. WORTH IT! The 15 minutes was a thing of the past when I got to taste these huge, scrumptious, dynamite burritos with amazing curry rice and with that fare of hot sauce that just screamed, MORE, MORE, MOOOORREEEEEEEEE! The burrito was huge so I split it with Sharon N and we walked to another truck for more, more, MORREEEE awesome goodness at Off the Grid.

Thanks to Esther Y for making sure I got some of this curry burrito goodness.

Credit cards accepted at this truck. Ya.
author: Zar A.

description: I had to wait around cause on the website it says they will be there at 11 am but they didnt come until 11.30. The food was okay, I had a lot of indian food so this wouldnt be the best, its just chicken tikka masala wrapped like a burrito. Nothing too special, i might try out something else.
author: Amber R.

description:
Awesome chicken tikka masala bowl!
Samosa was very yummy as well
Long line unfortunately but great yummy food
author: Ella B.

description: If you had Curry Up Now before and you just want to satisfy your craving, but not track down a truck then this is your place. Although the spice factor of the food isn't the best and they run out of certain things sometimes. The servers can be a bit aloof, but you can see they are trying real hard. I'd stick with the burrito or sexy fries.
author: Theresa D.

description:
I got the chance to try our Curry Up Now at OtG Fort Mason.  Sadly I only ordered one item: a deconstructed paneer samosa.  The samosa was absolutely worth 5 stars, but I think it's pretty unfair to rate so high when I've only tried one item, so I'll settle for 4 until I've had a chance to experience more.  

The flavors were amazing.  Just tons and tons of it.  I know nothing about Indian cooking, so I won't even try to tell you what sort of spices were in this, but let me assure you that it was delicious.  The crisp flour pieces were placed at the bottom, and the veggies and sauce were placed on top.  It was SO good, although this construction meant that it didn't stay crisp for long.  Loved it regardless, one of the best things I ate that day!
author: Vi N.

description:
A food truck worth food trucking for.
Curry up now shames many indian restaurants and shames many food trucks.

it's so much tasty!  I recommend the chicken tikka masala burrito, getting it xtra spicy is fantastic for me, but you probably can't handle it.  Ha ha, you wuss.  That's not true, I've cried from eating it extra spicy.  Still worth it.

The sexy fries are tasty, but always feels like it could be better.  When we decide to go to Off the Grid, we have to check the schedule to make sure Curry Up Now is there.

They take credit card!
author: Van W.

description:
alas, burrito 
paneer for the lady 
I am now quite full
author: Cole M.

description:
The burrito with anything trend is huge right now and this is one of the places that serves that.

I ordered the burrito CTM and it was delicious. I just love having the stuff wrapped around the burrito  because it was portable plus the extra 400 calories of the burrito wrap made it taste even better.

I'm not the one to go to if you want advice on Indian food, but for me, this place is worth trying and I will certainly be waiting in line 20 minutes to come here again.
author: Anthony N.

description:
I feel like a lot of food trucks haven't been living up to my expectations, so I was somewhat wary about Curry Up Now, even after hearing great things. Once I tried them, I was blown away.

The deconstructed samosa was genius. It's a very hearty item all by itself, and I love the mix of doughy components, chickpeas, meat and toppings. They may go a little heavy on the chickpeas, but chickpeas are wonderful, so it's hard to complain about that. I was really surprised by how much I loved the various chutneys, as I can be picky about those. These were all so flavorful and came together really well. The stewed chicken was fantastic and just spicy enough - probably my favorite part of the whole thing.

That chicken is also in the kathi rolls and is on par with the best tacos I've had. Approaches perfection. The potato ones are also delicious, although a little bit more bland in a wonderful, comfort-food type of way. 

I was surprised that I actually didn't love the burritos as much as I expected to. They were good, but I actually felt the tortilla didn't bring much to the dish (besides containment). On the other hand, my eating companion loves a good tortilla and routinely has them plain, just lightly heated, so he thought this was a good addition. The tikka masala was a little on the sweet side but the onions were fantastic.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Holy guacamole, the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito lingers with you the whole day. *burp* The whole day...

Naan-the-less, I really enjoyed the burrito. I liked the flavor of the curry and the onions were nice and crunchy. The chicken was mostly chunks of white meat. I would of preferred if they cut the chunks into a smaller size or even shredded them so that the chicken can absorb more of the curry flavors.

Lines are long during the noon time rush. But my 20 minute wait was worth it to try this $7 bad boy out.

Food coma happens.
author: Sam T.

description:
Til this day, I still daydream about Curry Up Now! I haven't had them in ages and finally broke that curse! It still tastes good as before!!

I decided to try medium spicy instead of normal chicken tikka masala burrito, and that was a HUGE mistake. It was soooo hot that tears were forming in my eyes (maybe the same time as tears of happiness?). Luckily I had a mango lassi and I also had leftover rice to mix together to tone down the spiciness. It was pretty much impossible to eat... lesson learned. No worries, I still plan on eating more Curry Up Now in the future!

Oh yeah... I used their iPhone app for the first time and everything went smoothly! Make sure you send it to the right location, though.
author: Janet H.

description:
Curry truck! Whoever heard of such a thing? 

Actually I think the concept of a curry truck warrants 5 stars. Great idea!! Curry Up Now is awesome and there's always a line. I finally got the chance to check this place out. So you gotta understand that this is fast Indian food, like super fast. They pre-make all the food. 

The mango lassi were on ice, but still not cold enough. Still tasted good though. All the burritos were also premade and my tortilla was a bit soggy. The curry was still good though. YUM. I was a bit sad they ran out of samosas. Oh well. Portions were very generous, I couldn't finish my food.
author: Cindy K.

description:
Met up with a couple friends for a casual dinner.  I ordered a kathi roll with chicken and a samosa.  The samosa was good, not greasy, good flavors, and the chutneys it came with were flavorful but not overpowering.  The kathi roll was ok.  I've had CUN's burritos before and was expecting a ton of flavor from the kathi roll and was kind of disappointed. The chicken was super tender but the seasoning was rather weak.  I can't even identify what it tasted like it was so "meh."

I had a couple bites of the sweet potato fries w/ paneer which was quite good. The guac sev puri was also ok - nothing spectacular or memorable but I enjoyed the one I ate.

Overall a little surprising considering what I expect from the CUN folks. I wouldn't rule out returning again to try the rest of the menu though. Those thali platters looked pretty awesome.
author: Naoko M.

description:
I had been on a 2 year, 3 month streak of not running into ANY food that was too spicy for me (since that one time a waitress warned me about 'nuclear' wings at a random pub, and I had to retort 'tell the chef to give me his worst'... bad idea).

And now my streak is broken.

All I asked for was a chicken burrito '...and make it spicy.' ...not 'extra spicy', not 'inedibly spicy', not 'I'm sick of having use of my tongue anyway spicy'... or anything like that, and yet, I found myself drinking coffee and eating random twix bars in my desk until my taste buds could recover.

That being said, it was pretty freaking delicious and huge for $8, and I managed to finish it despite my mouth being as close to actually on fire as it had been in a long time.

-1 star for the lack of warning though
author: Jake D.

description:
I am willing to break a sweat for the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito. 

I am a wimp when it comes to spicy foods, and the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito is on the boarder line. BUT, I will push my limits to eat it since it is so DELISH! Sometimes the spiciness will vary from day to day, but on a cold winter day, it will definitely warm you up!

I also had the naughty naan last time. It was a fluffy piece of naan with chicken curry and jalapenos on top. Oh dear this thing was SO SPICY... The taste was delicious, but I had to tap out after a few bites because my mouth was on fire, literally. I had to drink a glass of milk to extinguish the flames. 

I suggest coming to this place before noon or past 1 pm because the lines can get SUPER long. If they have a special menu item, I would suggest coming earlier since they might run out if you come later. 

Curry up now, we have a love/hate relationship, but I am definitely a fan!
author: Ayaka S.

description:
So simple. 

Chicken curry wrapped into a burrito.

But the tightly bound bundles of spicy goodness that Curry Up Now delivers - on a daily basis - are magical.

There really is no other word to describe - what makes people stand in line outside a truck for over an hour, when there are a plethora of other formidable eateries nearby.

It's the Curry Up Now magical spell.

Cast through a spicy rich curry sauce, and chunks of fresh chicken  - encased in a soft burrito tortilla.

One bite - and I guarantee you'll be hooked.  Fervently checking up on Curry Up Now's twitter feeds, and anxiously waiting behind the masses of people - outside Curry Up Now's truck.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
200th Review!

Maybe I should try other items that they serve, but I absolutely love their Chicken Tikki Masala Burrito. The chicken is tender and there is an explosion of flavor with each bite you take. The spices aren't too much, just a slight kick (this is coming from somebody who can't really eat spicy foods). The meat-to-filling ratio is about even as well so it's well worth it!

We had them cater one of our events as well. The only gripe I had was that the criss-cut sweet potato fries arrived cold. The employee arrived on time and was courteous. Found it interesting they didn't have something to help them bring in all the food we ordered though.
author: Kitty K.

description:
Highly recommended!!!
This was the most amazing western-Indian food I have had in years. 
Please try PTM sexy fries!!! I come from India and Singapore and I must tell you that there's nothing close to this in Singapore.
author: Rachit S.

description:
I grew up in East Oakland, so I am quite familiar with burrito trucks.The burrito truck has always been a symbol of community. It is a thriving hub, a gathering point of interest for all who desire a cheap, quick and comparatively delicious lunch. I remember spending much of my off campus high school lunches loitering around my local burrito truck, taking in all that community, oh yeah and all that grease and indigestion.

Fast forward to present. I am now a non-loitering working man in the heart of the Financial District in San Francisco. I spend much of my lunches not loitering, but still desirous of a quick, delicious and comparatively cheap lunch. 

I read about the Curry Up Now burrito truck in one of my favorite San Francisco food blogs, SF Foodie. I've always had a fondness for Indian food, but wrap that up in burrito?! Ingenious. Is it possible to take something so delicious and re-invent it in a way that is different but does not take away from the tradition of Indian cuisine? The answer is a resounding yes.

I ordered a Chicken Tikka Masala burrito, Desi spicy, via their online ordering system. When you go to the truck there are 2 lines, one for people who ordered online and one for people who didn't. 

When I took my first bite of my tikka masala burrito, I was overwhelmed by the creaminess and the burst of spices. The burrito is incredibly flavorful. But then it hit. This burrito is insanely spicy! If I could put the word "spicy" in all caps, then bold it, then change the color to flaming hot red and then change the font size to 57 I would. That's the only way to describe the inferno that ignited in the pit of my stomach. Goodness gracious. It was painful to finish the rest of this burrito, but I am not one to let food go to waste. Every remaining bite was painful. The heat of the burrito unfortunately took away from the delicious initial taste of the tikka masala.

If you are a lover of spicy food (or a sadist) go Desi spicy. If not then go (a lot) milder. Be sure to pair this food with your favorite dairy product (maybe 2 or 3 of them) because I guarantee you will need something to douse the fire burning on the dance floor located in the bottom of your stomach word to Sean Kingston.
author: Allan Y.

description:
This place mixes my love of Indian food and american food and mexican food together!  First of all try the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito, really delicious. Next try the Chicken Tikka Masala sexy fries, if you are adventurous enough (criss cut sweet potatoes with chicken tikka masala and cheese) TOO GOOD TO BE TRUE. 

Long line at lunch time, but it goes fast and is well worth the wait!
author: Aimee E.

description:
WOW....just Wow. The moment I heard there was a truck that served curry burritos, I knew I had to find it. Problem is that people keep telling me how rare it is to find it and when you do find it, there will be a line. Sure enough, they weren't kidding. After finding out they'd be here today, I knew I had to try it and get there early to make sure I get food before they run out. So I left for lunch early and got there with my friend Brenda around 11:45, thinking we were hecka early. Unfortunately, a ton of other people had the same exact idea. 

After almost 40 minutes of waiting, we finally got to the front and ordered our food. It was so worth the wait. Now on to the food. Let me just say this. When they say their food is spicy, they aren't kidding. Being a huge fan of spicy food, I got their spicy chicken tikka masala burrito. Even for me, a man who can take a lot of spicy food, this burrito made me sweat (and I loved every minute of it). The flavor was perfect and tasted simply amazing. I wish I had picked up some yogurt to put on the burrito to cool it down but I still loved every bite.

If you do come here, prepare to wait a while to get your food, but just know that it will be worth every second. 

CURRY NOW!!!
author: Gajan K.

description:
Yummy samosas! The chutney was especially great. 
Mango lassi was a little liquidy for my taste though.
author: Rowena L.

description: Sweet potato waffle fries with hot tiki masala is a piece of heaven. The lust worthy lamb burrito was tremendous effort in blending flavor, texture and on the go lunch food.  Kick ass fries did as promised
author: Robb L.

description:
I've now tried their chicken tikka masala burrito, paneer burrito, samosa burrito and the deconstructed samosa. To be honest, I'm not really impressed with any of it. The deconstructed samosa was the best of the lot, but not any better than you'd find in a passable Indian restaurant. The chana masala and curried rice they use have way too much garam masala so when you're eating one of the burritos, that's really all you can taste. Indian food is best when you can taste the sweet, salty, and spicy flavors all at once, but I found these burritos to be too uniform in flavor. The last time I ate there I asked for light rice and light chana masala, but it didn't make much difference.

Their burritos are really dense, which is great if you want bang for the buck or are just finishing a day-long fast, but they are likely to put you in a food coma for the rest of the afternoon.

I do understand why Yelpers rate Curry Up Now so high - the bar for Indian food is really low in SF. But save the fact that it's an interesting food concept (Indian+TexMex), Curry Up Now leaves much to be desired.
author: Paul S.

description:
2 words, deconstructed samosas.

Who knew garbanzo beans tasted this good? It's spicy too! And since it's deconstructed, I don't have to use a plastic knife to cut up the samosas into bite size pieces. Win!
author: Mabel Y.

description:
When I went to Off The Grid a few weeks back, I made a mental note to stop at the Curry Up Now stand to see what the buzz was all about

The line for Curry Up Now was one of the longer ones at OTG when I went, but it actually moves pretty quickly considering it's just a few people in the truck.  From when I put in my order with the girl to when the guy handed me my food, it was really only about four or five minutes max.  

The menu changes pretty often, but there seem to be a few items that show up regularly on their menu.  I really wanted to order both the Deconstructed Samosa and the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito, but I ended up going with just the former so that I wouldn't get full before getting a chance to try some of the other stands.

When I popped open the little take-out box, I was pretty impressed.  It looked delicious just sitting there, and I was pretty happy that it was a good sized serving for the $6 I paid.  Defintiely glad I only stuck with one item.  I ordered it spicy, and you could definitely get the heat through all those delicious flavors.  It wasn't the spiciest thing I've had, but in a good way since it wasn't pungent or overwhelming.  It's really flavorful, but I found it a little tough to break through the bottom layer with just a plastic fork to operate with.  Maybe if I was seated somewhere, instead of standing out in the cold...

Fortunately, I did up getting to sample the burrito I was eyeballing when my friend ordered one and let me try a bite before polishing off the rest of it.  I can't say too much about it since I got a bite of mostly tortilla and curry, but it seemed pretty good and I noticed a lot of people eating it.  She ordered it spicy like how I had ordered mine, but it didn't seem that hot to me.  However, it was probably because I had just one bite; she said she didn't feel it much initially until she had a few more bites and it started to build up on her.  That's some sneaky stuff there.

Would definnitely make it one of the better things to get at OTG (I still have yet to try you Chairman Bao), and definitely one of the better food trucks out there.  Seriously, Indian food in a burrito?  Genius!
author: Mike L.

description:
Not only is this one of the more popular food trucks in FiDi, but their workers are incredibly trusting and nice.  I ordered a chicken Tikki Masala burrito online and when I went to pick up my order, the lady informed me that they didn't take credit card (for online orders only I think...).  I asked if she can hold my order so I could go withdraw some cash from the bank one block away, and she saved me the hassle by just telling me to pay them back on my next visit!  Really didn't expect that but that was such a nice gesture.  

If you are craving a filling burrito during your busy workday, this is the place to go.  I recommend ordering online as the line sometimes gets out of control!  

As for the food...the Tikka Masala hit the spot.  Flavorful, saucy, mouthful of deliciousness.  Be warned, it's SPICY!
author: Kevin C.

description: I have been to their other locations and I like this one.  I love that you can order online and pick it up at the time of your choosing, makes it so convenient. The samosa deconstructed with paneer was great. Pretty unique and very flavorful.  I think this is one of the most popular food trucks in this area, there is always a long line.
author: Sunil R.

description:
I wasn't expecting to like the food as much as I did. I ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito and I didn't regret it at all. The chicken was cooked to perfection and the curry was scrumptious. I had never had an Indian burrito before, but now I can tell you that I'm definitely a HUGE fan. As someone who loves spicy food, I love the fact that they allow you to choose your own spice level. The burritos are pretty damn big, so I recommend not having a large breakfast beforehand.

Also, if you want to avoid the crazy long lines don't go around noon.
author: Abena O.

description:
Good chicken tikka masala burrito with loads of chicken. It's big! And thick! (Get your mind out of the gutter!)

I thought the samosa was good, but not something I care  too much for to buy again. My friend whom I ate with said that it was good and that she liked it. Maybe I will try to deconstructed samosa next time, however.. to see what it is all about. 

The mango lassi, for a first try, was different. Granted it was my first mango lassi, it had a very unique first taste and aftertaste. It is pre-made and was watery. Tasted like something I'd have to drink several times in order to appreciate. 

Aside from that.. I enjoyed the burrito the most and have some kickin' curry breath to prove it.
author: C C.

description: I tried the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito yesterday. I was not impressed. I thought Tikka Massala usually had Tandorri style chicken. This had was seemed like boiled flavorless chicken. The sauce was bland and watery.
author: Dezarae D.

description: Sexy fries. You'll thank me later. I mean, you can go for the staples - burritos, kathis rolls, etc., but if you want something a little new, go for the paneer sexy fries. Sooo much cheese, and in two forms, plus some crunchy yet soft crisscross fries. I mean, it's a little pricey at $8.50, but man, it is way too good.
author: Danny C.

description: Had the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito and it was not that great.  The chicken was overly charred.  Borderline burnt and the sauce lacked flavor and spice.  Would not go back for a while.
author: Raj G.

description: Delicious deconstructed samosa and chicken tikka burrito. Sexy fries with paneer were a bit soggy though. Love this truck!
author: Maxine E.

description:
WHEN YOU START YELPING FOOD TRUCKS... you know you got issues
(4 stars)

When India made love to Mexico, Tikka Masala Burrito was born to be one leading food item on the Streets of SF. I've been seeing the Curry Up Now truck down the street from my office in the Financial District for nearly a year (or so) and also at food festivals such as Off The Grid of SF Street Food Festival. Less then 2 months ago at the La Cocina SF Street Food Festival, i tried it for the first time. WHAT IN THE WORLD WAS I MISSING???!!!!!

TIKKA MASALA BURRITO ($6/$7) was SO amazing. It was a huge serving that we were able to split and share amongst 3 people. The line for this truck is ridiculously long but the line goes by fairly quick. 

* Ambiance - how can you miss this orange truck
* Price - fair
* Taste - delicious if you like Indian food. i like it better then Indian restaurants


Will I be back? Love this truck and well the truck got issues and is out of commission as we speak but i cant wait for it to start rolling around the office area again.

Until the next review.......
author: Jane A.

description:
Went there last Tuesday! Off the grid in Daly city . Since Sanguchon Peruvian was not there I decided to try something new!

Here I stand in front of the truck  service was neat nothing to  complain. Got a samosa it was filled with something like Humus and Dry peas. I felt like it was not cooked.

Got the chicken tika Masala burrito! And seriously I don't know  how people here said its good. AVOID YOUR SELF  FROM THIS. Dry Chicken, sauce was blend. The rice was  not cooked 
All the way. I don't know if they had  a bad day or  something but I wont be giving them another chance.

NASTY  NASTY NASTY! The did not even had a diet coke or lemons.
author: Jorge O.

description:
I work in London and I was down in SF for a few weeks. On day 1 we ordered some Kathi Rolls from this place for lunch at work. It turned into nuclear disaster for me. The rolls were very poorly and loosely rolled and wrapped and it fell out and disintegrated. 

London's (and NY's) Kati Roll Company forms my standard for Kati Rolls and unfortunately this place just didn't cut it.
author: Neelakantan N.

description:
11/29/12 EDIT:

It's funny: literally the same day as I posted the original review I decided to indulge, so headed over to the truck; my burrito was 3/4 normal size and the tortilla was 100% uncooked (cold, rubbery.) Ah, well, it was the end of their biz day so gave 'em the benefit of the doubt.

A week later I went again; it was raining heavily, but despite this the line was not only long - it wasn't moving at all. Like, literally. In the 10 minutes I clocked, the line literally did not move one foot forward. Perhaps this was due to a large party changing their minds or being clueless, or... perhaps this has to do with some of the new faces I'm seeing in the truck. I walked away after allowing 10 minutes to pass with zero sign of getting an inch closer.

And then a few days later I go to try them *again*...

So there's a new young dude who works this truck that has a serious attitude problem. Not only does he not acknowledge you with eye contact or reply to "thank you," he actually looks like he's contemptuous of you for eating there. WTF?! This turkey slapped my food in my hand like I was wearing on his last nerve, but... I hadn't even said anything (having dealt with a different cashier at the order window.)

So I go once more the next week - yes, I'm a glutton for punishment AND paneer burritos - trying not to think that this succession of completely disappointing visits was, perhaps, the universe trying to tell me something. He was there again. It proved to be the final straw. So so rude, surly... Mission accomplished dude: I don't want to see you again either.

Sorry CurryUpNow. I know finding decent employees is tough these days but you can do better than this kid. The equation is something like Quality, Service, Price. You used to have Quality nailed and Service was acceptable, cuz ya sure ain't cheap. 1 out of 3 doesn't cut it usually. You've lost me for now.

Guess I'll have to learn to make my own lunches, like I've been threatening to do for so long...
_______________________

ORIGINAL:

The PTM burrito is a flavor bomb. It is crack in a tortilla. It is the sole reason I don't dread lunchtime any more, even though I only get one a week usually... because just knowing it's an option makes me feel existentially better. It's a bit expensive, but I'm definitely not hungry again 2 hours later (or 4 for that matter), and so am OK with the $8 price tag.
author: Ronzlo L.

description: I tried this food truck last week on my lunch break. I ordered the vegetarian burrito and I am a vegetarian. Four bites into it I realized their was was chicken in it. I haven't eaten meat in 16 years so it took me a minute to realize why this burrito tasted different. They even announced "vegetarian burrito" as they gave it to me. I also tried tweeted then about it by all I got was a simple "I'm sorry". I'm very upset that I accidentally are meat, not ok. Usually Indian places are very vegetarian friendly so I am disappointed in this Indian food truck.
author: Chrissy M.

description: Pay attention to the reviews at the bottom of the page (greyed out as invalid?) this place used to be delicious but has gone downhill. They changed recipes or don't know how to scale. Plus the zombie workers there took 25 min to get my food. Not coming back .
author: E T.

description:
Tikka masala chicken burrito = spicy, savory, and delicious all into one ginormous flour wrap. Easy to handle.

Veggie samosa, is delicious, and it's vegan-friendly!

Total: $9.00 for my more-than-enough lunch.  

Wait: 20 minutes

Finding out that I could have called in the order and then skipped the line: irony. 

It was my first try here too. 

I was warned that it was spicy...so if you ask for extra-spicy...please know what you're asking for....:)
author: Fannie S.

description:
In one word- Delectable!!
Love their paneer tikka burrito while hubby prefers the chicken tikka version.
It gets a little crowded in the afternoon so make sure you reach around 12-12:30 to skip the long lines.
author: Swati P.

description:
Pretty promising.
They have a humongous menu and it will take me a couple of hundred visits to cover it, but I think I am up for that task!!
I tried some of their Bun Samosa (with tofu) and Papdi Chaat.. both were pretty decent.. Papdi Chaat I might order again..  bun samosa was meh.. I have had much better in India.
I wish they did not try to creatively remix everything.. SF doesn't have a good normal chaat place, and their creative remixing (like adding tofu chunks to the bun samosa) don't really improve the dish.
They seem more promising than Juhu Beach Club (the other hipster indian street food place I know of in the bay) which is great considering how these guys are in the Mission and Juhu is in far away Temescal.
author: Aditya M.

description:
My company must be as in love with food trucks as I am because they keep catering our corporate events. Earlier this week, Curry Up Now, HapaSF, the Taco Guys, and Let's be Frank were all onsite. The best part? Everything was free to us employees! Yipee!!
 
I made a beeline for the Curry Up Now truck because I've wanted to try their chicken tikka masala burritos for a long long time. There's just something about unconventional burrito/taco fillings that gets my salivary glands pumping.
 
And boy, it did not disappoint. I looooooooved the chicken tikka masala burrito! (The national dish of Britain lends itself perfectly to the burrito format. It's a wonder why no one thought of this sooner!) Loaded with spices, it was incredibly flavourful and one of the better tikka masalas I've had. The cubed chicken pieces--which they don't skimp on--were tender, the basmati rice was seasoned well, and there was just the perfect amount of tikka masala sauce (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AjuUljBC7tCMxX5eiWlzMA?select=PIYg5NTkZ4tQW7ioN2ELJw). I also liked the soft crunch from the sweet aromatic onions. Wrapping all that deliciousness up in a flour tortilla only made everything even better. Plus, all the ingredients were evenly distributed so I got a little bit of everything in every bite--an important feature in any good burrito!
 
I also got a veggie samosa (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AjuUljBC7tCMxX5eiWlzMA?select=6tM8jo4Y6h4bYYeNrWq-3Q) and that was pretty good too. It was big and filled with potatoes, peas, and lots of spices. But compared to the burrito, this was nothing special since you can find good samosas in most Indian eateries.
 
I liked the Indian chips they sell off the side of the truck too--very unique flavours!
 
Curry Up Now has the best of both worlds--all the flavour you'd get at an Indian restaurant without the lingering curry smell in your clothes, hair, and pores. Well, except for my fingers; they still smelled like curry after multiple washings...
author: Steph L.

description:
I was stuffed to the brim at Eat Real but all I could hear from my intoxicated friend was:
1. "I don't care how full you are. You HAVE to try this!!  Go get it.  Why the hell did you eat the other burrito?!"  (Refer to my Tacos San Buena review.)
2. "It was sooooooo freaking spicy; you will need some milk, oh yeah, you'll need milk."

I agree wholeheartedly with #1 because nowdays, any cuisine can be put into a burrito and the appeal factor increases exponentially.  The chicken tikka masala was no exception.  You can hold the whole meal in one hand with rice, chicken, lentils, and bell peppers.  As for the spice level, I could taste the spice but it was definitely bearable.

When I ordered this, the guy at the window said "finally", probably indicating that multiples before me all stuck with the paneer tikka masala.  Vegetarians are really no fun. 

My stomach was on the fringe of bursting so I had to save the remaining half for the next morning and it tasted even better then.  You know how when you save fast food, all the initial flavors usually dissipate so if it's good the next day, you know it's legit.
author: Shannon L.

description:
I was excited to try Curry Up Now...and was hoping for a curry rice bowl or something of that sort. Instead they had 2 types of Burritos, and Samosas. My friend ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito, and I bought the Veggie Samosa. The deep fried pastry shell of the samosa was yummmmmmmmay. The potato and veggie filling, eh- not so much. There was too much potato, not enough spices or other veggies. Some of the potato was dry, too. I prefer the samosas at Sukhi Indian Foods better (found at Farmers Markets). My friends said the Burrito was good.

2 snaps up cuz they had Indian music bumpin from their truck. It made their truck festive and inviting.  If I come across them again I'll try their Mango Lassi and something different to eat.
author: Rho T.

description: The Kati rolls are better than Kati Roll in New York. The chicken tikka burrito is awesome too!
author: H K.

description:
This place is right next to my work so one day I just decided to go for the plunge. I was pleasantly surprised and have now gone back 3 times. The chicken tikka masala burrito is awesome. I've also tried the deconstructed samosa. Also good, on the spicy side so be careful.

Overall, great experience. Next time hopefully I will come early enough to try the sexy fries. :)
author: Tara S.

description:
I enjoyed this interesting twist on Indian cuisine, but I'm not sure if the wait during peak times is worth it. 

The chicken tikka masala burrito was quite large and filling, but it wasn't particularly mind blowing as some of its proponents would lead you to believe. It was largely what I expected it to taste like which is a burrito filled with chicken tikka masala. It was a little too much food when considering it tasted rather one noted.
author: Victor W.

description:
DUDE I used the work across the street but never came here.. I don't know WHY.
A long line is ALWAYS a good sign, and DAMN is it worth the wait. I wouldn't complain 'cause the line at OTG is even longer.

TIKKA MASALA BURRITO FTW. At first, I was like, maaan $7 for this thing that comes in this dinky bag?? They pack it in this paper bag that's usually used for like.. cookies.
But when I ate it at work, it was the size of a normal burrito which is MORE than filling. OMG the sauce inside is heaven and it has a fair amount of filling.
My mouth was burning but it was a good burnnnn :) Can't wait to go again.

Usually I care about carbs .. but this is so worth the splurge.
author: Emily C.

description: This was actually the best place at Off the Grid. $6.75 for a Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=CAveDmi9tYg3Gbs9VVnm2Q&select=6qjf9O1ZIlz7jawO2ALxpw. Even though it was TOO SPICY for a regular, it was still the best item I had there. I brought my burrito home, added a lot of rice to it, mixed it in with the filling & used the burrito like naan. It was really good like that. Curry up now, I would come back for more.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Solid line, maybe a 20-30 min wait at Off the Grid Ft. Mason. But definitely worth it for the Indian-themed burritos and samosas. Was not overly impressed with the mango lassi, but I did like it.

Only ate half of the burrito, saved the rest for the next day and it was just as good!
author: Esther Y.

description: Solid tasty healthy Indian food - not too greasy. Chill ambiance, good prices, big portions. Didn't blow me away, but a generally good concept.
author: Andrew K.

description:
After being exiled to Oakland for the last two years, I'm working again in San Francisco. And although I'm chagrined by the proliferation during that time of those immensely annoying briefcases with wheels, I'm thrilled to be back to enjoy all of the great places to eat and drink. 

My most treasured find so far has been Curry Up Now. I'm not exaggerating when I say I'm addicted; I must have it at least once a week or I get sluggish and combative. The concept is pure genius; Indian food encapsulated in burrito form. Two of my favorite foods, together. 

Some of the reviewers complain about the lines, and that's a legitimate frustration. But the line isn't because of a lackadaisical team inside the truck. It's because this food is really effing good, and people line up in the rain for 20 minutes for it. I'm not exaggerating; last week a group of about 10 of us were huddled in the Wells Fargo ATM shelter in heavy rain, waiting for the truck to show up. And nobody complained; the line had the same friendly buzz as a bunch of hippies waiting in line for Phish tickets. 

As for the comments that it's spicy; it's not for the fainthearted. But the spice is very different from those hot sauces you buy at the Dallas airport that are hot just for the sake of being able to say "butt burner!" on the label. Curry Up Now's food has so much flavor that the spice isn't overpowering or gratuitous; it complements the food. And after a few bites you hardly notice the heat. 

Portions are generous without being ridiculous; it's a good value. The special burritos are always a hit, in addition to the standard Tikka Masala burrito. 

So to sum up; this place is awful and you shouldn't go. You'll just make the lines longer.
author: Jeff R.

description:
I had been trying to track them down on and off for the past six weeks. Our timings just kept clashing so much that the urge went from the shrill screams reminiscent of a toddler's tantrum to a more passive quiet murmur in the back of my mind... 

Two days ago, (somewhat) serendipitously, we crossed paths.

I ordered a mango lassi and a spicy chicken tikka masala burrito while my friend had the regular. They weren't as good as the burritos we used to make at home with leftover Indian food or my Mom's curry+daal + a little rice, and sometimes egg - but that's a pretty high (and unrealistic) bar. My Mom's curry is delicious.

Keeping in mind that Curry Up Now prepares everything in a small mobile kitchen, their burrito provides a unique & tasty option for take-out. Although, I must add, some bites definitely had more flavor than others. Those bites in particular were 5*-worthy, while others only 3*. (Hence the 4 star review.) I could've done with just a little less rice or a little more chicken tikka masala - but that's just me. My friend (who doesn't ordinarily prefer Indian food) loved it just the way it was. Their mango lassi seems rather diluted but has quite a kick due to the extra mint leaves as well as the lassi's acidity (which I like). However, it coming from a truck meant warmer than optimal temperature. Still, it's good overall if only flavor-wise.

The lines are long, so be prepared to wait a while. They've got a limited space for a few condiments right above the drinks, where you can find raita, achar, and whole jalapenos. If you want hot sauce, grab one of those little plastic containers and pass it to the person handing you your order so they can serve you some.

I'll definitely be back to try some of the other items on their menu and am especially curious about their kathi rolls, deconstructed samosas, & desi donuts.
author: Asha S.

description: Tried first time today. ctm burrito with desi hot was great. Its very spicy! The burrito was filling. I tried to save a half for later but gave up that intention after first bite. Inside was runny making it not a good candidate fir that. Beside you will probably want to finish all of that goodness. Will be back to try different items on the menu.
author: Tony T.

description:
I got the Deconstructed Samosa for lunch. Service was efficient, the waiting time was short, and the food wasn't bad. I picked the deconstructed samosa based on the Yelp tips, but I was personally surprised at the amount of garbonzo beans in the meal. The meal comes in a relatively small box. Once you open it, the entire box is literally FILLED with garbonzo beans. There's a few small pieces of chicken, the sauce was flavorful, and there were mini samosas inside the box as well. Garbonzo beans get a bit dry if they aren't combined with too many other ingredients, which ended up happening for this meal. 

It wasn't bad, and I'm definitely coming back for the chicken tikka masala burrito! I've heard too many good things about that item haha
author: Jeannie W.

description:
One of the best places I've found to eat in San Francisco, Curry Up Now serves an interesting twist on the run of the mill burrito. I eat here more often than I probably should, but I really can't get enough of their delicious burritos, and judging by the regular lines, either can anyone else. There are choices for our vegan, vegetarian and meat eating friends alike, and while I'm normally a sucker for chicken, their paneer tikka masala is by far my favorite.

The burritos themselves come with a perfect blend of rice, beans, filling of choice, and a healthy dose of spiciness. The spiciness can vary from day to day, so don't be surprised if you don't remember it being as hot or mild as last time. And speaking of hot - these things burn! If heat is for you, then you should be happy, and if not, they come in a mild form too.

Although my stomach lining probably hates me, I'll be back soon. By far my favorite food truck.
author: Brandon S.

description: Got delivery here and loved it! Of course you can trust SF to have innovative Indian food trucks. The deconstructed mimosa is to die for, and so is the tikka Marsala burrito.
author: Julie D.

description: I'm not really digging the burrito + curry + rice thing. Too much carbs.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
Curry is absolutely one of my favorite things so I was excited when Curry Up Now's lunch stop today was right across from San Jose State. There was a line when we got here but it moved quickly once they opened. I was surprised to see that they only had two items on the menu, but apparently it changes on a daily basis. We got two chicken tikka masala burritos and one chicken deconstructed samosa. FYI, they DO accept credit cards.

The deconstructed chicken samosa was delicious! The samosa was bathed in a savory chutney that had onions, tomatoes, and garbanzo beans. They drizzled the sweet tamarind sauce as well as the green herb sauce traditionally eaten with samosa into the chutney. Spices were wonderful, though the samosa turned mushy because of the chutney. They went a little overboard with the garbanzo beans and by the end I was eating spoonfuls of beans.

The chicken tikka masala burrito totally lives up to its reputation. One bite and I was smitten. It was a decent size for $7. The chicken was cooked well and the spices were right on.

They had a white sauce that I guess was made from yogurt from the consistency and taste. Tasted good with the burrito and samosa. The veggie mix was very strange. It had a sharp and sour flavor, like something that was pickled for too long. Didn't like it.

The food was awesome! They'll definitely see me again. They have a restaurant opening on April 15th in San Mateo. Might go check it out sometime.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito. This burrito is legit. It has the perfect blend of rice, garbanzo beans, chicken tikka, and masala. 

Be warned, the burrito is pre-made for the food truck. It's just as good but if you want to have a fresh one, you have to go to their store in San Mateo or Palo Alto.
author: David N.

description:
I'm just not sure... All the reviews seem to love this place, but, I was just, ok about it.

Had the chicken tikka masala burrito.  I told them, just a little bit spicy.  Wow, if what I had was just a little bit spicy, I can see how some people would die eating this stuff at regular spicy.  

Maybe it's the norm, maybe it's because I got one of the last 5 chicken tikka masala burritos they had left, but, there was barely any chicken in it.  A lot of rice, some chickpeas, and some decent flavors, but, I wanted chunks of chicken and they were no where to be found.  

For $6.75, it's definitely decently priced, and filling.  But, I think next time I crave myself a chicken tikka masala (it's my favorite Indian dish) I'll walk over to "Curry in a Hurry" and get the lunch special for $6 instead.
author: Cindy C.

description: The food is certainly good, it's around the corner from the office. The problem is I try to get there before they close and they are always out of the most popular items. Frustrating, so instead I went to the food truck that's new right next door.
author: Just N.

description:
Went to SJ Eats Food Festival event in San Jose today and tried the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito for $7 and the Kahki roll with chicken $6.
Both were tasty, I would say I've never had Indian food in a burrito style or roll, but I'd go back for more if they were in the South Bay.

The Tikka Masala Burrito was a little more spicy for my taste, but I enjoyed it still.  Burrito had spiced rice, onions, chicken, and some other ingredients.
Kahki roll was made with Roti as the outer wrap which was a little greasy with oil coming out the bottom but green chutney (I think) sauce as a spread and onions and chicken chunks.  The roll I didn't feel the heat (spice) as much as the burrito, but don't take my word for it.  My taste buds are excessively sensitive to spice so to most it probably doesn't even seem spicy.

Try it once and you can judge yourself if you are ever in the neighborhood.
author: Linda P.

description:
DAMN, this stuff is spicy.

The Chicken Tikki Masala Burrito is great. The creamy sauce is wonderful; the rice is great too. The chicken was flavorful as well. The mango lassi is a great way to kill the heat from the burrito.

The deconstructed samosa is great. The spice is strong, but its still good. 

I love going to off the grid and getting this food. Although I will warn you, they sell out of the mango lassi within the first couple of hours and they make the burritos beforehand, but that's all okay. 

Will have to try some of the other stuff; the naughty naan...sounds interesting.
author: Nina Y.

description: 4.5 stars for their unique "Tikka Masala Chicken burrito. ($8 I think). It's a food truck (that has a restaurant in San Mateo) that has a bunch of dishes, but you really only want the chicken curry burrito, it's great. Everyone loves tikka masala, now put it in a nice burrito and it's greatness to go in your hand. Get it.
author: Chuck N.

description: Have always had a solid experience with their truck. CTM burrito, samosas and deconstructed samosas, sexy fries, all delicious! Usually the line is out the door (or down the block in case of the truck) but it has always been worth it. Only downside - went to their storefront at a non-peak hour (3pm) and my friend and I's food was very cold! She got CTM burrito, I got deconstructed samosa, and we shared sexy fries, and all were really cold. Like, refrigerator cold. Normally I would not recommend this, but I say go during a busy time so you definitely get a freshly made, piping hot dish!
author: Sarah B.

description:
After many times seeing this truck outside my building with the loooong lines, I finally tried it. Waited 20 mins even though I got there around 11:30am, which I thought was early. Overall it's good, but not sure if it's worth the long wait. If there was a short or no line, sure, i would go for it again. They run out of stuff towards the end of the lunch rush.

- Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito: a bit dry, good flavors, really spicy! (i got the spicy one), chicken pieces good
- Mango Lassi: thick and not overly sweet, wish they served it colder instead of room temp
author: Linda C.

description:
I'm eating the CTM Sexy Fries right now. So interesting--sweet potatoes, spicy curry, and cheese--and so well crafted. I recommend this if you're into spicy Indian food with the substance of sweet potato fries.

Curry Up Now outshines all of the food trucks I've had in the Financial District. Their daring fusion of sweet potato fries and chicken curry make the line wait well worth it.
author: Kaleb L.

description:
Ordered the goat curry over rice special. I got about 3 morsels of goat, the rest of the lumps turned out to be shards of bone. It was also way too spicy. I love spicy food, but this masked the flavor of everything else. In fact, I would wager that the extra spice was added to numb your esophagus so you wouldn't notice it being punctured by the bones you didn't realize you were eating.

Seriously, the bone shards were potentially lethal. I'm ok with a few bones, but a warning would be good (required?). Replacing the meat with bones and disguising them with sauce is downright criminal. And for $10.
author: alistair h.

description:
Located around the corner from another truck that is so passé to still serve Mexican burritos, this welcome addition to the otherwise unimaginative FiDi street food scene will rock your burrito world!  Love the fact that you can order  online (without committing a  prepayment) before 10:45AM to pick up your food at noon.  Bypassing all those hungry office workers (desi and non-desi) feels better than skipping past a velvet rope!!!  The burrito is a meal and a half, so you might be best with a ThumsUp instead of a more pedestrian samosa.

Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito (Desi Hot): Watch out Mexico, your burritos are becoming irrelevant!  Chick peas instead of refried beans or black beans.  Spicy methi pulao instead of yellow rice.  Cliantro mint chutney instead of salsa.  Tender tandoori tikka chicken instead of the flavorless pollo asado.  And for once, hot means HOT!  The whole experience is like eating a spicy chicken biryani in a tortilla wrap which makes it portable and adds a good chewy texture.  Love the crunchy, slightly pickled onions because all the other spices must not have been enough alone to enhance your post-burrito breath!  Much more flavor complexity than any Mexican burrito I've ever had.

Paneer Tikka Masala Burrito (Desi Hot): All the goodness of the chicken burrito, but with cheesy goodness instead.  The paneer was the right texture, chewy and slightly dry like homemade (as opposed to that bad store bought stuff).  Wish they would have seared it a bit though to add a crunch.

Samosa: Got this as a $1.50 combo upgrade with my burrito.  Not overly greasy, but too salty.  Also a bit bland.  Disappointed that not sauces were given with it.  Guess its better to stick with the fusion here.
author: Adam B.

description:
Me: Hi, I'd like the paneer tikka masala burrito, spicy please.
Food Truck Dude: It comes with a kick. You sure you want it spicier?
Me: Yes, please, extra-spicy.
FTD: So how spicy do you want it? You want it really spicy?
Me: Yes. Extra spicy.
FTD: OK, cuz it's gonna be really spicy.
Me: (getting annoyed). Yep. That's what I want.
... 10 minutes later, handing me the burrito....
FTD: OK, this is REALLY spicy. You sure?
Me: I know I'm a white girl, but yes.

Seriously, dude?

I'm half way through the thing and my nose isn't even running. Also, it's not really that great.  :/
author: Amy A.

description:
Naughty or nice.

Santa prefers you act nice.

Curry Up Now prefers you act naughty.

Specifically with their Naughty Naan, a delicious open faced sandwich topped with chunks of chicken tikka masala, greens and onions. Cheese and jalapeno are options too.

Loved the sandwich even though I wish there was more chicken. Bit light compared to the size of the naan and the $9 price.

Staff was great in answering all my questions about the various items and packing up my order to go despite a Blackboard Eats restriction that stated otherwise.

As you'd expect much more seating than their truck: http://www.yelp.com/biz/curry-up-now-indian-street-food-san-francisco-3#hrid:_Bg_w3ZST4xnb_8vHmJolw. Burrito is still my favorite.

Nice is usually the way to go. Occasionally being naughty never hurts.
author: Jason B.

description:
Oh Curry Up Now. Even though you made me wait for 30 minutes out in the cold during Oakland Art Murmur, I FORGIVE YOU. Even though your greasy pork belly burrito made me wipe my shiny lips feverishly on a brown paper bag every two seconds, I FORGIVE YOU. I think I may have scared a child or two with my haphazard eyes and grease face while eating on the curb, but somehow, you made it all okay.

Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito: I was first taken aback by the spiciness, because I'm used to the heavy, rich, creamy tikka masalas of Berkeley Indian restaurants. I was pleased to find that the burrito contained a very generous serving of chicken.

Pork Belly Burrito: This was on the special menu, and it was well worth the wait. This wasn't as spicy as the tikka masala burrito but there was enough of a kick there to keep it from being overly rich. Lots of grease, but who the fuck are we kidding here. This is PORK BELLY. In my opinion this is better than the tikka masala burritos on the regular menu. Spend the extra 2$, because the pork belly will bring the party to your tummy.

Come early, because they can run out of certain special menu items. If you're visiting the truck at a popular event, be prepared to wait a bit for your order.
author: Hanui C.

description:
I'm obsessed with Curry Up Now.  I am not just replacing "I like" with "I'm obsessed with" to be cute.  I'm pretty sure thinking about curry all day and getting on the subway a few times a week to hit the Bush truck for lunch merits "obsessed."  

I love this truck so much.  People seem to have a low tolerance for spiciness--I'm not judging, just noting--because I would describe the spice level "moderate."  It makes my nose run a bit but it's not FIRE IN MY MOUTH status at all.  More importantly, their food is delicious.  

Here are the things I eat at least three times per week:

Tikka Masala Burrito: the crown jewel of Curry Up Now, this thing comes packed with your chosen meat or cheese tikka masala, pickled onions (I love these things and could eat them on their own, breath be damned), rice, and some garbanzo action.  It's amazingly, magically delicious, and it's $8 for at least two meals (I'm an average-sized female so maybe one meal for you burly men or 4 meals for you waify supermodels).

Deconstructed samosa: This stroke of genius is a smashed samosa topped with garbanzo action, chutneys, and your chosen meat.  It's savory and has more flavor than the burrito.  It's the food snob choice, but I'm often lured back to the burrito when I need more of a curry kick.  The decon isn't actually curry, contrary to popular belief.  ...I'm not sure that's true since the definition of curry seems to be "some spices together" but it's definitely not tikka masala as in the burrito.  

BOTH OF THESE ITEMS ARE AMAZING.*  I really can't overstate this.  I've had a ton of Indian food from all sorts of places, but I'm in no way an expert, so I'm not going to compare CUN to Indian food as a whole.  I have no idea how authentic it is, nor do I care.  Curry Up Now does not speak for all of Indian cuisine.  It speaks for all of delicious cuisine.  Try it, love it, go back, borrow your friend's car to go to the restaurant, suffer dreams about it, call in sick to a meeting so you can curry up, force your spice-hating friends to love it, become That Person who just talks about curry all the time...

Maybe it's actually a life ruiner, now that I think about it.  Avoid it at all costs.  At the very least, it'll ruin your local sandwich shop for you.  More curry for me.

*Other menu items are delicious as well--I just consider these two the stars of the menu.  Feel free to construct your own opinion and write me an angry message.
author: Eliza L.

description: Delicious! Everything is amazing! Ive never been disappointed with their food. I usually get the sexy fries or the deconstructed samosa with paneer and chicken ;). The lines are long, but definitely worth the wait!
author: Natalie B.

description:
After waiting in line for 40 minutes, it was WELL DAMN WORTH IT! My co-workers and enjoyed their KurKure chips and their monstrous burritos. 

We ordered the Green Monster (Lamb) which had a HUGE kick! Make sure to get some of their yogurt. 

We also had their Tikka Chicken which is very flavorful. 

Very much impressed. Good concept, Good food, tooo damn long of a line.
author: Scott L.

description:
Awesome!

I've caught up with Curry Up Now twice now, once at the Eat Real Festival in Oakland over the summer, and today at CUN's Monday hangout in the Financial District. I've been highly impressed both times.

At Eat Real, I ordered a "deconstructed samosa." The description fits the product quite well. The crispy breading is of course the best part of any samosa, and it makes an appearance in the center of the deconstructed version. The filling is a great mixture of beans, potatoes, and spices (it's quite spicy!) In total, it's significantly larger than a "constructed" samosa; it's a small meal in and of itself.

Today I ordered a regular samosa and a Chicken Vindaloo burrito. The samosa wasn't nearly as good as the deconstructed version, but hey, it's hard to go wrong with spicy potatoes in a deep fried batter. 

The Chicken Vindaloo burrito was fantastic. It was huge; I definitely didn't need the extra samosa. It also happened to be extremely tasty. Well spiced, well cooked chicken (I didn't think it was too dry as others have said), and great rice and beans. It was pretty spicy, so get something else if that's an issue for you.

As an added bonus for capsaicin-o-philes like me are the spiced chiles they offer as condiments. They were extremely tasty and added an extra kick to the already well-kicked meal.
author: Adam B.

description:
I'm a purist, and the biggest advocate against anything "fusion." If you're going to do a cuisine, my motto is: do it authentic, do it right! 

But alas, it looks like I belong to a fading regime of fusion-haters in SF, where anything and everything is put together and made surprisingly, better!

Perfect example of this: Curry Up Now's Chicken Tikka Masala burrito.

Yummmmmy! Alone, the chicken tikka masala sauce was really, really good. The creamy sauce hit every note: savory, spicy, and spicy. Combined with the tender chunks of chicken and flavorful rice, all wrapped up in a soft flour tortilla, every bite was an explosion of flavor and taste sensations. I vaguely recall sour cream, fresh avocado, and garbanzo beans, but I can't remember. My eyes were rolled back into my head and I was DEVOURING the burrito.

Curry Up Now has become one of my 3 favorite food trucks in SF (the other 2 being Chairman Bao and 3-SUM). A definite must-try at any Off the Grid gathering of food trucks.
author: Monelle A.

description: Great food. Been here couple times but they never let me down. Love their deconstructed samosas the most although their whole menu is yummy. One of the must try food place in city.
author: Angela -.

description:
OK I Am pissed offffffff !
The quality of food here is inconsistent ... Maybe Americans cannot see the difference.
People flock up and make a line which is a mile long, but is it really worth it ?
I have been to this place many times, and every time the experience is different, mostly bad !
I believe the curry up staff has become complacent since the food is selling a lot. But  saying that the truck opens at 11:30 and then opening it at 11:45 is not acceptable. We have work to do  !
Then they take up bulk orders and cannot keep up with it.
After a long wait, order no.20 was delivered, but my order no.10 was still not ready. I mean common..you just have to mix 4 things in a box !! I had to intervene and ask if there was any progress on my order. I could clearly see that everyone was making burritos and nobody paid attention to other orders. Then after 15 minutes, I am given my food.

Curry Up..you do not respect my time, I am not coming back.
author: P D.

description: Expensive and I feel curry too sweet. 12:30 would still have a long line. Whole wheat wraps are gone by then.
author: Shin T.

description:
Curry Up Now is just okay.  Their CTM burrito is not as satisfying as a burrito from your fave taqueria, and if you're looking for Indian food, not saucy enough either.  But it's worth a try.

The CTM burrito has components of a burrito and it's spicy and dry. You got your basmati rice, chickpeas, and chicken.  It's a bit expensive (8+ dollars) and I really just felt like I was eating spicy rice wrapped in a tortilla with bits of chicken surprises.
author: Biqi C.

description:
I've heard  about and have desired to eat the chicken tikka masala burrito for some time. Finally, today I got the chance since the Curry Up Now truck was at the OTG 5M site.

Given all the hype and the possibility of a huge fail I ended up being completely satisfied. One of my favorite curries is chicken tikka masala and to transport that into a burrito is inventive and ingenious. If it wasn't so damaging to my health I could alternate either eating this burrito or the Kim Chi bulgogi burrito at John's Snack and Deli every work day lunch. Sushirrito is a distant third imo.  

I still want to try the deconstructed somosa as that sounds interesting.

I did not have to wait in a really long line so my experience was pleasant. I paid and got my burrito instantly. If I had to wait 30 minutes it would have still been worth it.
author: Jack C.

description:
I've come out of my yelp writing hiatus to drop some love on Curry Up Now. I've been meaning to catch this truck for a few weeks now. It seems that they usually take Monday's off, and I'm usually got that leftover fuzz of a hangover from the weekend still going on that calls for burrito on a Monday afternoon. Thus my dilemma. Finally, I came across the chance to hit them up today. I got to the truck right around 1:00pm. The truck was scheduled to be at 225 Bush between 11:30am - 2:30pm. There was about 12 people in line when I got there and a good 15 or so more loitering around for their orders. The line was slow, and everyone behind the counter was busting ass so what can you do. I get up to the window and a guy comes out and writes sold out on the chicken masala burrito.  

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AjuUljBC7tCMxX5eiWlzMA?select=JARwUU46RYsjwcSi_orR8w 

Like literally the person in front of me got one, and I did not. Sad, sad Vigler. So looks like I'm getting the special "The Kashmiri" which is a fresh la palma flour tortilla, kasmiri pulao, dama oluva aka dum aloo, pickled onions, chana & unOm. Now considering my mouth was watering and I was thinking of the different ways I was going to devour the chicken tikka masala, this was pretty good. It's probably a solid 4 star combo. It was fairly spicy. I was surprised, I'm sure many are probably crying about this, but really if you don't want spicy, go to taco bell and stop ruining good food for the rest of us.

I guess next time I'll have to go even earlier to catch the Chicken tikka masala.. I thought I was ok showing up 1.5 hours before close, but maybe it is that good! Only time will tell. I'm saving my 5 star upgrade in the hopes that this bad boy, really does kick me where it hurts.
author: Paul V.

description: CTM burrito is pretty darn good and a decent size for the price. I think I'd still prefer Berkeley's Urbann Turbann over it for the variety of ingredients that they have (no chutney in this one!) But Curry Up Now's CTM burrito was still deliciously warm on a cold day and had a good savory mix of flavors. I would come back for it!
author: Veronica C.

description:
I tried the chicken tikka masala burrito and despite the warnings of spicy being way way too spicy I tried it anyway. Ok people, it is spicy but you only need one glass of ice water for the whole thing unless youre a super lightweight . Its really tasty and I'll get that again.  Yum. 

Two days later I was gonna try the decon samosa but the gal in the window said I should try the Kahti roll since it was after 2pm and that's when they start em. I posted a pic of it. I got the beef, also spicy. I dunno if they are always supposed to be that greasy or cuz they had to re-deep fry em real quick to warm it up. Very tasty but I won't get that again cuz I like my arteries. 

I will get the decon samosa next time. Nice concept of different things each time with only 2-3 staple items. 

If you're in the fi-di sf, Twitter them to find out if they are there and check em out.
author: H D.

description:
Love the mobile unit that is CUN. I have a very strong love for Indian Cuisine and Culture.. Of course Indian women too. But this review is about CUN. They have 2 mobile units that travel. They have great variety, the Paneer Tikka Masala burrito is amazing especially the spicy version. Limca [Indian Soda], Lassi, Khati rolls, Roti. They have a lot of wraps both vegetarian and meat. You can order from various menus and levels of flavor.

They are real Indians and they do live by the IST [Indian Standard Time]. They aren't Mickey D's. They take the time to prepare the food. So, if you're in a rush, or on a short break, you might not have the time to wait in line, order and eat. They do take online orders. They fill up really quick. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because I haven't tried everything. But, what I have eaten is so damn gooood!!!!!
author: Erik R.

description:
Being from Sacramento and disappointed in the Sactomofo food trucks, I was super excited to try the food trucks in SF! 

So the first one I stumbled across the this Curry Up Now Food truck on the corner of Bush and Sansome. I ended up ordering a Mixed Paneer and Chicken Tikka Masala burrito. First time having Indian Burrito! Although, I feel like SF likes to make burritos out of everything!

The line was a bit long and the burrito was decently priced at $8 a pop. The burrito was actually quite tasty and a novelty to my taste buds. I forgot to order spicy as I'm a huge fan of spicy, but the mild did have a little kick to it. My gf got the spicy and did not like it as it was too spicy for her, but not spicy in the way she liked. 

Overall, I would definitely have this burrito again. The thing was huge and pretty tasty. Not the best thing I've had in the world but yummy nonetheless!!
author: Phuoc L.

description:
Chicken Tikka Masala burrito is nom nom! Would be 5 star but the online ordering process is a bit broken. I also considered using the APP to order but the reviews were terrible citing that orders placed with the app aren't communicated to the truck. 

I Placed my order online but they had no record of it when I arrived. Go figure. They were good about getting me the food I paid for but sorta defeats the purpose of ordering ahead of time - or even having that option.

Chicken Tikka Masala is really good. Ingredients tasted fresh and delicious. I asked for a little extra spice in mine and blam, they delivered. Runny nose - affirmative.

I'll definitely repeat.
author: Jase O.

description:
I forgot my lunch at home today, so I went for a walk around the FiDi.  I came upon the line for the Curry Up Now truck and decided to give it a second try.  I had at chicken tikki masala burrito over the summer, and didn't think much of it.  Thought it lacked flavor and was filled with too much rice and potatos.

However, this time I got the Special K Burrito, and was very surprised at how good it was.  This time, the balance or meat to rice was perfect.  The flavor, soo much flavor and perfect spiceyness (perfect for me anyways, some might find it too spicey).  Had to wash it down with plenty of Thumbs-Up Cola!  

With the exception of the 20 minute line, it was a good experience.  I will definitely be back.  Next time, I'll pre-order!
author: Veasna H.

description:
I just took my car for a smog check down at the place next to Safeway on Market St. Unfortunately, my friend got a migraine so my plan to drop off my car and grab lunch was foiled. I was hungry, however, and saw the Curry Up Now truck parked in front of the smog check place. So what the heck - I thought I'd check it out. 

I asked the guy in the truck what was good, an he said most people usually get the burrito their first time. Okay. Sold. I got the chicken tikka masala burrito. Since I was getting self proclaimed "Indian street food," I figured there was no better place than the smog check parking lot to take a seat and start tearing up this burrito. 

Verdict? It was awesome. Outstanding flavor. A good amount of chicken, and just the right size. Definitely filled me up. The last time I had Indian / Mexican fusion was at Avatar's in Marin (word to the wise: don't try to run a 10k the morning after eating there. I learned the hard way.). Anyhow, this place was way better than Avatar's, and it came from a truck! Looking forward to coming back at some point. Unfortunately, I couldn't check in as apparently yelp hasn't figured out how to let you check into something that is always changing places, like a food truck :-). Anyhow, check it out! Awesome food! I can't wait to try something new.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Their indian burrito was one of the best things we tried at Sactomofo 4.  Curry chicken and rice and such in a burrito? Brilliant!  The contents were awesome all on their own, and then you add the portability of the burrito.  The consistancy and construction was just right so that you could eat it without it getting everywhere.

And the burrito was pretty big for the price.  A solid 5 stars on this place!  Ill be back for sure!
author: Chris K.

description:
I can't decide between 2 stars or 3 stars, so I am going with 2.5 :-)

I've driven down to the Brisbane truck for lunch about three times now.  The first two visits were fine - nothing to complain about the food and service.  The location is nice in that you can park your car in the adjoining lot and eat in there once you get your food.  Today's visit, however, left a sour taste in my mouth and I don't know if I'll be coming back to this CUN location.

I usually get to the truck around 11:30, before the mad lunch hour rush comes flooding in.  Even then the service can be slow, but it ain't getting any better than that.  

I wanted to try the kathi rolls today but was told that they were out of the bread.  I then attempted to order a few samosas, but they were out of that too.  I don't understand how they cannot have ingredients for some of the most popular items on their menu, and at such an early hour.  I went ahead with a paneer tikka masala burrito bowl.  Luckily that had THAT...

During my two previous visits I always paid cash, but almost everyone else in line paid with a credit card and had no problems.  I took my chances today without cash, hoping I could use a credit card.  The cashier didn't know how to log into the iPhone credit card app and tried calling her boss numerous times to get the pin code to log in.  It sounded like her boss didn't have a clue either, so the cook joined the party and tried saving the day.  She did this with a few people patiently waiting for their food in the Brisbane breeze (there was only one cook at that time).  This circus went on for 10 long minutes, until they finally got into the app somehow.  My credit card was accepted, which prompted others in line to take theirs out, only to be promptly told NO credit cards after me.  You can just imagine the confusion among everyone right now.  It was kind of hilarious.  Some people stayed in line, looking confused, and others threw in the towel and left.

It took another 10 minutes for the cook to realize she couldn't successfully log into the app either and that there were lots of people waiting for their food.  She eventually prepared mine but never called my name out when it was ready.  I was standing in the cold wind like a moron waiting and waiting.  The cashier finally called me over and apologized for the shitty service and wait.

The food: The paneer tikka masala was much oilier than I'm used to.  I thought I would get the same fillings that are put into the burrito (chutneys), but I guess not.  The mango lassi was the shining star of the day, but come on, how can anyone mess that up?

In short, I don't think it's worth my time to drive from the city to this CUN truck location, especially if the two gals from today are going to be running the show from now on.
author: Nina V.

description:
I have eaten at Curry up now quite a few times. I loved it when I ate there the first time! Their chicken burrito was awesome. However, lately its consistently not been good. 

Deconstructed Samosa: The samosa is served all soggy, and therefore there is literally no taste of samosa and the serving of chickpeas in this meal is way too much! Hated it.

Paneer Kathi roll: The paneer was soo chewy that I had to take it out of the kathi roll and just eat the bread as my lunch. Other than being chewy, the preparation did not have taste to it. It was just plain paneer and maida (all-purpose flour) roti. So not like Kathi roll. Kathi roll's USP is that its made with wheat flour indian-style bread.

Goat Curry: Smelled sooooo good, tasted totally opposite. Just a combination of garam masala and goat. No taste.

Chicken Burrito: Too saucy and again no taste to it.

I wish the owners of Curry Up Now soon realize that they are losing the Indian taste from their menu each day. Would love to eat there again if they improve their preparations.
author: Parminder Nayyar C.

description:
This review is for the Curry Up Now truck that came to Brisbane on 1/22/14. This was my first time trying this truck out and since I had a pretty good Indian dinner not too far back, I decided to try this out.

I ordered the tika masala chicken burrito...it tasted great but after about an hour or so, I started feeling a little "sick". That sickness lasted pretty much the rest of the day and caused me to stay home the next. I know it wasn't just me because my co-worker got sick as well.
