Get there early, or pre-order on line to avoid a long wait.
author: Ken B.

description:
Such a unique experience that encompasses a burrito filled with chicken tikka masala; and deconstructed samosas. Although I cannot take spicy (I literally cried while eating my grub from Curry Up Now), I still persevered as it was that good.

IMO, I enjoed the deconstructed samosas a lot more (less spicey, therefore more doable) plus I like how the potatoes at the bottom are a bit crispy and have their skins on still, and how they're little samosas in the deconstructed. A work of art, I say.

Line is usually long, but def. worth the wait for this unique eating experience!
author: Christina C.

description:
Deconstructed samosa. First tried it from truck in Burlingame. Then had it at Off the Grid. Way too spicy. Pretty oily, and practically can't break apart the samosa at the bottom with the fork. A bunch of us could eat spicy, but it was just a bit too much.

Would be 2 stars, but I remember the one I had before was good, and maybe we just got it too spicy, so 3 stars it is.
author: Anita C.

description:
This white boy is impressed.

I got the spicy chicken tiki burrito and, holy shit, it actually met my standards to what spicy means.  I give mad props to them for actually making the "spicy" version runny nose and sweat-worthy.

Besides that the burrito was really flavorful, filling (couldn't finish it), and not heavily laden with cheap ingredients (not a rice and bean bomb).  The chicken was good, and although I was expecting a fair amount of gristle, I didn't have any bites where I felt the need to spit out chicken tendons!

Thumbs way up!
author: Rocco B.

description:
The chicken tikka masala burrito was like manna from heaven on this blustery cold summer day.  

Chicken was moist, white chunks with no scary pieces that sometimes occur in other food trucks.  

Spices were gorgeous; not too hot at all.  A little extra heat would have been fine.  

Portion HUGE!  Had to force myself not to eat the whole thing b/c it was eye-roll inducing delicious.  Perfectly complemented with a rich mango lassi.  MMMMMM.
author: Erin C.

description:
I returned. I ordered it spicy. I fell deeper in love.

Spicy is equivalent to spicy at your standard Indian restaurant, which isn't totally murderous, but rather zesty and enticing. It cools down as the temperature of the food cools down, so don't let that first bite scare you.

I cannot and will not stop eating Curry Up Now.
author: Stumbalina b.

description:
I walked by this truck on my way to Noah's bagel, i had just heard of this place this morning from the La Cocina street food fest so I decided to check it out.

I got the spicy chicken tika masala burrito.  This is probably the most spicy burrito I ever ate... Even more spicy then the suicide kimchi burrito.
.....and now I'm paying for it in the bathroom.  Yes, I'm typing this review on my phone, while in the bathroom

It definitely hit the spot and is worth a try.
author: Damon J.

description: When they say spicy, they mean spicy! wowza! even the mild was too spicy for me. The chicken tikka masala burrito was solid. a little bit sweet, unique, and filling. However, I would have to say the kothri roll was my favorite. tender, flavorful, perfectly cooked chicken.
author: Angela H.

description:
Tiki masala + burrito = genius!  

If you work down here and need a quick fix for some Indian food in a fast-food-sort-of-style meaning quick, easy and portable then this is the place to be.  Genius!  And, don't forget the spicy lime chips...
author: Zac M.

description:
I've only had the chicken tikka masala burrito.  The chicken was slightly dry, but well dressed by the creamy and spicy tikka masala.  Overall pretty good, but I prefer the fresh-out-of-the-tandoori-oven chicken tikka masala naan rolls served at Jack London Square Farmers' Market on Sundays.

**For my full review on foodtrucks around SF, visit my blog link under my profile. Enjoy!**
author: Karin V.

description:
I'll just add to what others are saying...

Chicken. Tikka. Masala. Burrito.

It's awesome! I can't bring myself to order anything else here. 

If you have a gentle mouth, don't get it, it's HOT!
author: Wes K.

description:
Really good food, I dig the Twitter thing with the menus, and did I mention really good food?

Monster line, and while it moves reasonably quickly, it's not like you're going to be out of there in five minutes. Such is the price of success, I suppose.

The well-meaning gal taking orders kept trying to convince me the special mystery burrito was too spicy and exotic for me. I appreciated the first try, but if a white guy repeatedly tells you he likes spicy South Asian food, quit trying to pimp the tikka masala already. Give the big bearded man what he wants, whether or not you think his German / Irish blood can handle it. It can, he did, and he'll be back.

Four stars because they tend to run out of food, supplies, etc. Show up early.
author: Mark W.

description:
Delicious, I usually try to review somewhere after eating there a few times, but I can't help myself.  My co-workers and I were actually heading to get the Kim Chi burritos this week but were persuaded my the delicious smelling curry that we stopped at the truck.  

Although there was a decent size crowd there at 12:30, the wait was reasonable for both lamb and chicken options.  Thanks Curry Up Now for this, you know we're all "so busy" at work we can only sneak away for a short while sometimes.

I got the Chicken Tikka Masala, spicy and it was soooo good.  And spicy means SPICY, in a good way as I was still able to eat the whole thing.  Obviously, burrito+rice+chicken tikka masala is very filling; for health reasons, I'd recommend to share one of these logs and get a side salad somewhere as well. 

$$$ wise very reasonable, my burrito was $6.50, a bargain for what you have to pay in the FiDi area.  Also a fan of the music to pump the crowd up!  Looking forward to coming back soon and trying other things on the menu.
author: Laura H.

description:
I've only had the Chicken Masala burrito, but I've had it 8x - by my standards, that's a five star.  

It's a whole lot of tasty Indian food for $7, one minute door-to-door when at the McCoppin Off the Grid (and 5 minutes from where I work when in Redwood City).  

I've always wondered how it would taste if it was wrapped in a naan?  Anyways, 5 stars for fulfilling cheap, tasty and convenient.
author: stuart l.

description:
Curry Up Now is one of the best food trucks out there! I've been there twice now and will be going back many more times. I recommend ordering the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito, and then make it a combo (you get a samosa and a mango lassi) for $4 more.

For a guy who regularly orders CTM at Indian restaurants, and then eats it with rice and naan, this burrito is perfect. It's really flavorful, and will make you really happy.

I'll be back for sure. Give this place a try, the lines aren't nearly as long as they used to be. You should be able to walk up without pre-ordering (though they have an online option) and get your food within 15 minutes usually.
author: John C.

description: I tried their PTM burrito. Without their hot sauce, it is alright. But with the hot sauce, I was transported to a universe where poverty, disease and war didn't exist. These guys are awesome. Must-Visit in SF.
author: Shriphani P.

description:
I drove to Palo Alto from my work in Santa Clara for it. OK, not just for it but the mochi as well at Moxsie Street Eats.

The line was quite long, little over a dozen people in front of us. I was hoping that our food would come relatively fast considering it was a food stand. It did not. We waited and waited some more. My co-workers got so hungry that they started eating their mochis. Didn't pay attention if anyone had a particular huge order but I saw 2 and 3 burritos by the pick-up window but nobody was getting their food quick enough.

The portion was generous. With all the sauce, it could get real messy very easily. Good thing we drove back to the office (it rained and we had to hurry back due to the wait time) because I started using plates and forks halfway thru. 

Call me wuss, it was spicy! For the first few bites, I thought it was nicely spiced but the rest really caught up to me. I liked the pickled onions. Overall, it was nicely flavoured, just too spicy for my taste.
author: Cindy B.

description: Burritos are good.  Was very disappointed today to arrive and be told they had NO HOT SAUCE.  That is the only reason I order from them, to have a scorching burrito.  The blog posted about traffic delays on the 101, but failed to mention anything about inventory issues and a lack of hot sauce.  Worse yet, I had ordered online, so I was stuck.  CUN, you failed today.  Please do better to keep your customers informed.
author: Colin S.

description:
A taco truck "roach coach" serving indian to-go made-to-order, mexican taco truck style? Curried Burrito fusion food, and big samozas to go. Yes! 

You get to choose the spice level (hot is great, but my stomach is the wimp my tongue laughs at) and regular is tame but tasty (if you eat Indian food at all, I can't imagine you'd need "mild").  5 star only because that is awesome for a taco truck; this isn't high-end indian food, but for a $6.75 burrito off the curb, it can't be beat!

Co-worker says "I haven't tried it because there's a line". Of course there's a line...it's called repeat lunch crowd for a fine little business, genius! 

A chicken tikka marsala burrito is strongly recommended, you'll be sold.
author: John G.

description:
This is a decent Food Truck, I can't say it's the best indian I have ever had. I tried their Chicken Tikka Masala and thought it was decent.

One thing for sure is you know if it's good when you see a line of all Indian People waiting to get their orders from the truck.

Note: I went to the Food Truck in Redwood City. It's a 3 minute drive from work, so I'm happy that they are close by whenever I have an indian craving.
author: Eric A.

description:
Let me start out by saying that I am rarely a fan of Indian OR food carts.  This place may just be the beginning of me changing my mind.  They have managed to find a great combo between authentic Indian food and Americanized presentation.  It had the feel of an old fashioned taco truck, but the line of the latest and greatest new restaurant.  In fact, the line was really what drew me to this place.  I use to work across the street from here and always would see a huge line of people waiting out to get something from this truck with fancy writing on the sides of it.  Today I was walking past it as usual and the line was not nearly as bad as it usually is so I decided to give it a try.

The menu isn't very big and it changes daily (maybe more than once a day).  The one thing I've always seen on it though is the Chicken Tikki Masala burrito.  I think it's their staple there and if you go for the first time I would recommend that.

I'm personally having a hard time trying to decide if I like this place or Chaat express better.  When I think of Indian food I normally think of buffet lunch, but both of these places have capitalized on putting that same food inside of wraps.
author: Brian G.

description: Always long lines here. I had the CTM burrito twice. It's good but it isn't fantastic Indian food. They have mango lassi's ready to go though. Worth trying if you haven't been before. Best to go early around the top of the 11:00am-ish hour for the shortest lines.
author: Jorge S.

description: I'm a big fan.  A curry burrito sounds wierd, but it tastes awesome.  I tried the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito and a goat plate.  The burrito was great, and it was filling to the point where it might be a little too much food.  And although I liked the goat plate, it was a little too spicy and it would have been nice if they had fished out all the bones for you, but it was still good.  I say try this if you enjoy indian food.  It doesn't taste like normal indian, but it's still good!
author: Charles Y.

description:
I had heard about this truck from a colleague and had to try out this San Francisco phenomenon of eating from a truck! And this truck was 21st century all right-plus it looked clean and the long line ensures good turnover of food.

There was a line all right, but we all waited patiently for curry goodness. Tully'f coffee did not miss a beat and delivered samples and coupons to people waiting in line. I had the deconstructed samosa (paneer) and asked for spicy! I clearly overestimated my ability to withstand heat and OH BOY! was I in for a hot surprise! Up to the point where my taste buds were working, the whole thing tasted DE-LI-CIOUS! 

Go for the regular kind but if you are up for the challenge make sure to grab multiple containers of regular yogurt to appease your mouth and of course a mango lassi. 

Also, there's a cool indoor patio around the corner with nice tables and chairs. I think it might be CHASE bank.
author: Florencia P.

description:
Review haiku:

Ate a burrito
Desi hot is REALLY hot
Thanks, will come again
author: B K.

description:
My Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito was delicious!!

In front of City Hall today around 1pm.
author: Wakaknee J.

description:
There was a line before the truck even got there today.  'Nough said?

The food is delicious and well seasoned. Some may find it a little on the spicy side, however I find the heat for both the Tikka Masala burrito and the deconstructed samosa to be, as Goldilocks would put it, just right. 

The only reason that I didn't give five stars is just because I have a hard time with waiting just as long (or longer) for food from a truck as I would waiting at a sit down restaurant, and most of the times I've gone the credit card machine has been on the fritz.

Still, the food is good and I will come back again... and again... and again!
author: Roxie J.

description: I got the CTM (chicken tikka masala) burrito. The idea is pretty innovative, but the chicken tikka masala was too spicy and the taste was just off. Wouldn't recommend it.
author: Aneesh S.

description: Paneer kathi roll was bland and chicken tikka burrito was average, Mango lassi was awful..only the Samosa was good. overall was very  disappointed as I walked over a mile to get to their truck.
author: Vivek S.

description:
LOVES their chicken tiki masala burrito...so yummmmmy and SPICAY!!  good size anf fills you up sooo much!

their pandeer is goood toooo..you wont even miss the meat in it..
author: Cali L.

description:
Been noticing this food truck on Bush for a while now during the walk from BART to my office...that indian food smell just wafting throught the streets as you pass, luring you in! I finally stopped to try it today, around 2 pm, which seemed like good timing, as there was only a short wait. I got the paneer tikka masala burrito. It is a pretty massive portion, just like a mexican mission burrito but with a slightly different flair! The paneer was quite fresh - not rubbery. The chickpeas were very tender. It was also VERY SPICY - even for me and that says a lot, because I am a hot sauce whore and I pack it on! No need to here - it was already in the mix. Hot hot heat, like the kind that makes you start sniffling (as to whether that's good or bad, you be the judge!)

I appreciated the fact that the filling was wrapped in a flour tortilla rather than a piece of naan, making an already heavy meal slightly less filling (I have had other tandoori wraps elsewhere, and they always tend to use naan). I found the menu to be humorous - as a vegetarian - they referred to the veggie options as "om" and the meat ones as "un-om" or "not-om" or something. 

Definitely a two meal deal for me ($7). I would like to try the samosa at the later date. Don't think I would hunt them down on twitter or whatever - as the street food movement seems to encourage - but nice to see them around in the FiDi. The other people waiting in line, by the way, were all super uptight financial district people, which sort of took the fun social vibe out of the experience but hey - not my problem. Thanks for lunch.
author: Shannon R.

description:
This place is awesome. I used to work on the pennisula back when this place only had 1 truck. I heard recently that the owner has gotten even business to now have 3. They are doing something right because I think it hasn't even been around for more than a year. Chicken Tikka burrito is awesome. If you can't deal with spice like some of my friends, let them know. The deconstructed samosas are good too but the burritto is just too good to pass up. You can follow their twitter and facebook days to see when they will be around . The updates can range from a mechanical problem with a truck shutting down a location temporarily and sometimes there are surprises at new locations or even special treats too). 

If anything it's just intriguing enough to try at least once .... but you will be back or at least have a craving for it again later.
author: Greg G.

description:
Curry Up Now is the one of the few places where I would say they serve good spicy indian food. This stuff is SPICY, my sinuses were clear and I could breath after this clear. 

Instead of the normal beans and rice, they have garbanzo beans with Methi Pulao.  

The reason they get 3 stars is the meat was dry and not very tasty at all. (Apparently they have recognized the issue and are addressing it, I'll update as soon as I try it again). I recommend not getting the onions since they're don't break apart easily when you're eating them so you have dangling pieces of onion in your mouth. 

Maybe if the meat was cooked properly then I would give this place 5 stars.
author: Rohan D.

description:
If the premise makes you want to go, then you'll dig it.

I'll concede that the execution (of the tikka masala, etc..) could be slightly better of course, but the concept is amazing and the service is great too.
author: Robert K.

description:
I got to try the Samosas. They were either $2 each or 2 for $3 
They weren't that amazing. All I could taste was the potatoes.. i didn't get any peas or anything inside. Bummerrr. BUT THE SAUCE did make it yummy!

The Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito was really delicious! Had lots of chicken bits in pieces in there :)
author: Jenna L.

description: I work at Montgomery and Bush so the truck is almost unavoidable. I've grabbed lunch here twice before: the first time it was good, the second time less so and my order was wrong. Today I saw the '$10 Pork Belly Burrito' sign and had to stop. The pork belly was cooked perfectly but the rest of the burrito was so soaked in grease it leaked through the tortilla, the tinfoil and the paper bag, got all over my hands and my dress and left the burrito inedible. I won't be back.
author: Brandi M.

description:
This curry/burrito ("currito"?) truck with a line of 20 people sparked my curiosity. 25 minutes later, my curiosity led me to "test" their spicy chicken tikka masala burrito. I'm glad I did. There was no wait for my order and the burrito size is appropiate for being under $7. Every delicious bite was accompanied by sweat drops. I finished 4 cups of water while eating this thing. I should've ordered the lassi to soothe some of this heat. Maybe next time. And there will be a next time.

Do not order the SCTMB if you cannot hang with spicy.

I can't resist quoting Apu from the Simpsons: "Good rice, good curry, good Gandhi, let's hurry."
author: LM M.

description: Love this food truck. There should be one parked on a corner in every part of the city.  I'd been looking forward to trying it for a while now. I didn't do anything too exciting . . yet . . . I just got the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito. It was delicious and I didn't even have to wait in line very long to get it . . . granted, it was a cold low-foot traffic kind of day. I look forward to going back often and trying the rest of their menu.
author: Lauren B.

description: Awesome food! The pork belly melts and the sexy fries is oily but heaven !
author: Shyna H.

description:
My review is for the food truck in Mountain View on 10/4.  I was hoping they would have the nice food truck mounted with CUN logo but we go the white truck instead. 

It was about a 15 minutes wait in line.

The menu is pretty straight forward but for someone who has never tried Indian food, it might take some time asking what certain items on the menu were. 

I ordered Paneer (cheese) burrito as well as the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito. I tried the Samosa and I thought it was just okay.

The chicken tikka masala burrito was my favorite. It was $7 and quite filling. 

I have to say I LOVE the GARLIC ACHAAR (pickle).  I am in the process of finding a menu to make it.  Love the flavor of the paste and the tiny bite of the onion.

As always, I had the preconception that it would be hard to find parking but it wasn't. It was right on the parking lot with plenty of space.  It was hidden so you have to follow them on twitter of facebook to track the truck down.
author: Jboogie L.

description: Chicken Tika Masala + burrito = my favorite lunch, maybe ever. The 'hella vegan' burrito is also pretty delish. And SOOO filling. A meal to last you all day.
author: Mindy M.

description:
FINALLY! I've been wanting to try this food truck for so long. My friend's keeps talking about it, but I never seem to be free or in the neighborhood during the times they are located.

I caught them when they were at Bay Area Brewfest.  This place was good, but the spiciness was a little bit overpowering for me to fully enjoy it. If they tone down the level of spiciness than it would be one epic Chicken Masala burrito.
author: Tina T.

description: I have been a regular at this truck for almost two years now. The quality has been steady for sure and they keep adding cool new items on the menu. Now the challenge is stepping out of my comfort zone and trying the new specials on their menu. Keep it up folks!
author: Z L.

description:
The line was pretty long when I got there (~11:30 or so?) but it moved okay and once I ordered my Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito came out very quickly.

5 stars for the food
-1 star because WHEW the "mild" was spicy (or maybe I'm just a huge wimp?)

I suppose next time I'll have to ask for extra mild - I want to keep eating here but I can't handle this much heat on a regular basis.  It's sad.

The mango lassi (the only thing that saved my mouth!) was indeed more savory than usual, but very good.
author: Audrey C.

description:
aaahhhh, food truck food!

yum yum...chicken tiki masala burrito!  Two of my favorite foods put together to form some kind of hybrid that you can walk around with and eat!  Makes me want to wrap up other things in a tortilla and see what happens.

It's yummy, but the really bad thing about this damn thing is that its so big, you become so full you don't have any room to try what I assume is all kinds of other deliciousnessness (sic) available!  

I'm must track the truck down and eat the other stuff on the menu and update this review...stay tuned!
author: Jason Y.

description: I don't know what the hype is all about with this truck. I love Tikka Masala but in a burrito, it's just a mess and difficult to eat. The tortilla breaks apart and I basically need to eat it with a fork anyway. Much rather eat my Indian food at a restaurant.
author: Diana U.

description:
I stepped outside yesterday to accompany my coworker to get food and there in front of me is the Curry Up Now truck!  Not to mention the line at least 10 people deep.  

Indian food (tikka masala or paneer) inside a burrito!  Gotta love it! 

Personally, I thought that the tikka masala burrito was a little dry and could've used some sauce to go with it.  I was actually dreaming about the Naan 'n Curry tikka masala sauce inside the burrito with a side to dip in as well.

I will be coming back here next time they're in town though to try their deconstructed samosa.  I heard good things about that one
author: Allan H.

description:
I feel like i got bamboozled.  I've heard nice things about Curry Up Now and have been encouraged to try it.  Being an Indian woman who loves Burritos, I thought it was worth a whirl.

I took a look at the menu and decided on the CHicken Tikka Masala Burrito which reads, "Chicken Tikka Masala, onion pulao, sweet tamarind, sour cilantro, mint chutney, and jalapeno.  This sounds good.  I order, ring it over to my table, and unwrap it.  Only to find my burrito stuffed with Chana (chickpeas)..

 Now, nowhere on this menu did it say chickpeas but i went with it anyway and thought, "maybe there are just a few that somehow got in there."  Nope, not the case!  There were about two pieces of chicken in this entire  burrito.  

I understand if you ran out of chicken but considering that there are atleast 10 people on your line at all times and you're trying to compensate for lack of an ingredient, i think you could charge 50% off.  I paid $8 for  chicken.  Not only did you falsely advertise but you also charged me the same for an ingredient that costs more than 50% less for you to use and make.

With that said, I'm open to the possibility that my order may have been a fluke but I won't spend another $8 to find out!
author: Mo M.

description: If you like spice like I do, then you'll LOVE Curry Up Now.  Save yourself some time and order on-line before you arrive.  This allows you to skip the line and just head to the pickup window.  My only advice: if you like spicy, order spicy and don't order DESI.  The spice comes in 3 levels: mild, spicy, and DESI (death by curry).  Unless you truly have an asbestos mouth, heed my warning.  My normal order is the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito and I haven't been disappointed yet.
author: Sean H.

description: I love this food truck!  Delicious Chicken Tikka Masala Burritos and the Sexy Fries are awesome.  The spiciness varies day to day, some days can be pretty hot.  Lines real long sometimes but typically moves quick.  If you don't go at rush hour it's usually not a long wait.
author: Chris P.

description:
I got the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito and it was UNREAL.  Why have I not had Chicken Tikka Masala wrapped up into one convenient package until now?!  It was the perfect thing to walk away with and eat on the go.  Not cheap, but a hefty load o' food, and sooo tasty.

Loved it so much that I changed around a lunch date with a friend when we saw the Curry Up Now truck from afar.  Told her she HAD to taste the Chicken Tikka Masala - the salad lunch can wait.  She was not disappointed.

Super nice folks, too!
author: Riza O.

description:
The Paneer Tikka Masala burrito is soo good- I really need to try something else.   

The line can be a drag, but they seem to have gotten their system down because it moves a lot faster now.   

I would definitely tell a friend about this place- on second thought, no I wouldn't.  That would mean more people in line.
author: Scott T.

description: It's not bad and the service is good, but this place won't blow you away. You've definitely had better Indian food, I guarantee. This is just a novel delivery mechanism.
author: Jay N.

description: Wow, that was easy, delicious and totally affordable! Next time I forget my lunch for work, I'm going here! The vegan deconstructed Samosa was AMAZING!
author: Dani S.

description:
Just had my first meal there, the chicken burrito (the actual name had some extra words but that's what everyone was calling it), and it was fantastic: lots of chicken and fresh rice saturated with very tasty curry sauce. I just finished it and am already looking forward to my next trip to get the same thing.

Oh, and it was fast too ... I ordered, handed over $7 and was immediately handed my nice hot food.
author: Roger H.

description:
Their PTM Burrito is amazing! Holy crap that thing is huge and there're so many different flavors, spices and textures going on. The rich curry, the soft rice, the tender paneer, the crunchy onions and the firm garbanzo beans all work so well together.

If only they went the extra mile and put it in naan, that's all I ask. Some soft buttery naan. Or even a roti but come on, a tortilla?? Your delicious curry deserves better.

None the less, I'll be back because of the delicious curry, the friendly service and even the reasonable price but NOT because of that tortilla!
author: Mack D.

description: Let's just say. I went to Off the Grid at Fort Mason this past week. Got a CTM burrito from Curry up Now. They gave it to me instantly, but the flavor just wasnt the same. For one, it was warm at best, which is never good in my book. I want my food to be hot. Like burn the roof of my mouth hot. And especially given the windy weather, the CTM burrito did nothing for me.
author: Jessica H.

description: The Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito is fucking awesome. Don't forget to ask for hot sauce. The yogurt drink, a mango lassi, is also a need because it neutralizes the hotness. Careful 'tis spicy.
author: Grayson K.

description:
I have to say that eating Indian food in a burrito is a pretty novel idea, but at the same time how could you mess up anything with that buttery masala sauce? 

I think I'd still prefer going to an Indian place.
author: Leily P.

description:
great place for a stop and go. Their chicken tikka masala is a fav. Before when asking for extra spicy, it is not just spicy.... it is indian spicy.

the good: chicken tikka masala
great service, the people there are very personable 
close proxim for folks who work nearby

the bad: lines can get long at times, get there early, the place usually comes by around 1130
author: Saul M.

description: I've literally been dying to try Curry Up Now because of all the good things I've heard. Let me tell you, it's not all talk. I thoroughly enjoyed my Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito from the Food truck I visited while on Treasure island yesterday. What in the world did this meal do to my taste buds? It made them explode with loads of flavor. The burrito had me full for days & the price was pretty decent. An $8 burrito I wouldn't mind paying even $10 for? Oh man oh man. It was good stuff. The spiciness of the curry was a tad overwhelming at times but I love that! If you really knew me, you'd know that for breakfast, I drown my eggs & meats in tabasco hot sauce. Therefore, this place is amazing. I definitely want to go back and try more of their food!
author: Kai S.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars but I'm going to round up to 4 because I love the concept.  Coming from a country where street food is the norm and not something you have to hunt for, I am a huge fan of more street food in SF!  

I ordered the roll while my two friends ordered the chicken tikka masala burrito.  I loved that there was a layer of fried egg on the roti, and the chicken inside the roll was tender and flavorful.  I was left feeling like it could have been bigger - maybe some more veggies?  I tried my friend's burrito, and while it was tasty, I was incredibly disappointed with the dry chicken.  If I were to get a burrito, I think I would go with the paneer.  

We went to city hall around 12:15 to check out the food carts, which was a mistake since it was prime government lunch time.  We waited about 15-20 minutes in line, then another 5-10 for the food.  If you don't want to wait in line, I would recommend going there before the lunch rush, or heading there around 1pm.
author: Carmen L.

description:
Came here a couple weeks ago with my coworkers and waited in line for 30 mins. It was prime lunch time, so I expected a line. I ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito (regular $6.75) and a samosa ($1.50). The lady warned us that the spicy burrito was pretty spicy. Right when I ordered it, I was handed my order. Good job! I didn't have to wait!

We all found a place to sit and eat. The regular burrito was pretty spicy but very flavorful. There was a lot of chicken pieces, beans and rice. The burrito is very packed in, so you get a lot of food for the money. The samosa was pretty tasty as well. I really enjoyed the food, and its in the fidi! Will come back here for lunch!
author: Betty S.

description: My British side thinks really spicy chicken tikka is brilliant. My California side thinks Burritos are awesome.  When CUN puts the two together ... Magic!   Just be sure to ask them to make it properly spicy if you want an experience.  Their other stuff like the deconstructed samosa is fairly decent, but It's definitely not up to the same standard.
author: Neil S.

description:
My favorite new lunch spot.  

First timers: get the chicken (or paneer) tikka masala burrito...don't ask for it spicy, it's already has plenty of that.
author: Warren H.

description:
I used to walk down Bush St at lunch near my work and see this food truck parked with a loooong line of crazy people waiting in it. I wondered what the big deal was. Then, one day, bored at work, I decided to stand in the ridiculously long line as it was a nice day and I wanted to satisfy my curiousity about this food truck.

I got the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito (regular, not spicy). It was divine! I totally understood all the crazy people and have now become one of them. Clearly I am not alone as CUN has a few food trucks who now travel all over the bay area in high demand. I crave it and follow the truck so I can see when it's on Bush St again.

P.S. The second time I ordered it spicy...it was still wonderful, but be prepared for hotness.
author: Stacey H.

description: Best Indian Tacos ever I have. From my first time to today, I stopped counting my visits...but the taste is awesome. These guys are so cool, well mannered and so fast in service but without any mistake in creating orders. I was amazed for first time when I saw Vegan options there. I have Vegan friends and it is hard to find places where awesome vegan foods are served. Though I am vegetarian and I cannot hold myself for visiting them at least 3-4 days a week without getting bored with their food.
author: Sawan P.

description:
Visited their truck at the 'eat real' food festival in Oakland. We had the chicken tikka masala burrito and the flavors were awesome. The ingredients were fresh. We went in to get more burritos to go. I would definitely go back. 
Highly recommend.
author: Nancy D.

description: I'm not sure what they put in these masala burritos, but they are extremely addictive.  I follow them on their website and try to catch them in Brisbane, SSF and OTG.
author: Food N.

description:
eh...

Don't like waiting in a huge line for lunch.

Don't like that this place charges $8.75 for a puny quesadilla - I mean it's from a truck for goodness sakes - you're not paying for ambiance.

The samosa was good - but not work spending 25 minute in line. I like the condiments. The pepper sauce stuff has a great kick.

This gimmick will run it's course.
author: Chili B.

description: Last time we hit up CUN @ Brisbane it seems like they got the s**t together.  Maybe a different van with a different crew, but super nice, good portion size, fast service.
author: Roni L.

description:
Finally, my San Francisco dream has been realized because I have partaken in food truck fare. Curry Up Now rolled into my SOMA workplace and like the other 500 excited people, I stood in line for about 30ish minutes for a chicken tikka masala burrito. Chicken tikka masala = good. Burritos = good. Chicken tikka masala burrito = eh . . . good, but probably not AS good as either of the originals. But then again, burrito form is probably the best way to eat CTM for lunch anyway. 

My burrito was probably just the right amount of spicy, but my the end of the burrito my mouth was on fire. I had to drink milk afterward just to move on with my day. Oh, and I really should have stopped about 2/3 into that burrito, because I was STUFFED for the rest of the day. But then again, I have this problem with all burritos; because I love tortillas, I love the ends of the burrito, so I always try to power through to get to the good stuff. And then I regret it. 

Oh, and I had to take away a star because I hate puns. Ick.
author: TamaleGirl G.

description:
Tikka Masala Burrio has changed my world. I love the samoas too, such a nice treat! Of street food, Curry Up Now is King. The best cart in the city. Not always the fastest, but always hot, filling and yummy. A must try for street food fans. 

(However, last time I ordered a mild at off the grid upper Haight, they gave me a super spicy one, it burned my tongue so bad! But I'm forgiving you guys because its amazing 92% of the time)
author: Halley B.

description:
*Just changed my review from 3 to 4 stars because Rana, the owner, wrote me an instant response to my review below, saying there will be some adjustments.  Yes, folks, good service is alive and well!*

I've got a thing for the Decon Samosas.  Sometimes I wake up craving one and I plan my whole morning around getting to the truck in time so as not to wait 30 minutes.  But, even on days when I'm first to arrive, I still have to wait 20-30 minutes.  Usually the truck is on time...Gotta give these guys credit for really sticking to a schedule.  But, you have to give them time to prep the food and set up.  By the time they open for biz, the line is half-a-block long. Not a fan of the tikka masala burrito, myself.  It's a little on the sweet side.  But, lots of people love it and it's not nearly as spicy as the samosas.  The surprise menu items and very friendly staff are what will keep me checking in with the CUN truck.
author: Amilee K.

description:
When I (over)heard my coworker talk about an Indian Burrito I knew I had to give that a try. I love Indian food and I love burritos... together they should be amazing, right?

I ordered the chicken tikki masala and daaaaaaaaaaaaaaamn it was delicious. i chose regular instead of spicy (because im weak) and it was perfect. and for the price it was huge. I was starving and I was only able to finish a lil more than half.

the bf got the deconstructed samosa with ground beef. I took a few bites and found it to be good too. (but not as good as my burrito!)

all in all, it was delicious and worth a try!
author: Stacy L.

description:
God bless the Internet: Curry Up Now saw my displeased review and sent me a message, letting me know that I might have accidentally received a "spicy" burrito, as opposed to the normally-spiced version.  They asked me to come back and try it again on the house, and God knows that I never turn down free food.  Because what's the worst thing that can happen, right?  I get a another oh-my-God-too-spicy burrito and I add it to the compost bin... while starving children in rural India cry.  

I will say: this burrito was much, much better.  Still REALLY spicy, but not to the point where my mouth turned to sandblasted, painful mush.  Once again, I did not finish the entire burrito, but this time it was because it was just way too much food, and not because I felt like my esophagus was on fire.

All in all, 3 stars for a pretty legit burrito, and an extra stars for the super-duper customer service.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Came across this while looking for Indian food on yelp and were excited because (1) we have a food truck obsession after watching "The Great Food Truck Race", (2) it's a place to get food in Brisbane and (3) the reviews made it sound phenomenal. Perhaps it was the high expectations, but we came away disappointed.  

The Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito was good, but not heaven-sent.  The deconstructed samosa (beef) was mushy and incoherent, and the regular samosas were quite oily.  The mango lassi had an interesting kick and was good. And as other yelpers have mentioned "regular" is spicy, so their food is not for those with GI sensitivities.  

Restroom review: N/A
author: J S.

description: Had the tikki masala burrito and was impressed on how flavorful it was.  It had just enough spices.  Maybe a lil more chicken would be nice but overall very good and will go back for more!
author: L E.

description:
The only drawback from this place is that their Desi hot chicken tiki Marsala burrito is not very hot.  I was hoping for some real spicy burrito but unfortunately I had to ask for a side Desi sauce to apply more on the burrito.  Even after applying that on my burrito it still lacked the necessary heat.  Other than that the burrito was delicious!  

Their deconstructed samosa was interesting but you should just order the regular samosa as the deconstructed didn't warrant the higher price
author: Frank L.

description:
I have only tried a few items from Curry Up Now during some Off the Grid events, but it is definitely one of my favorite food trucks in the bay area. The chicken tikka masala burrito is my favorite. I have only tried the regular, but its already REALLY spicy. Despite how spicy it is, I can't stop eating it once I've started.

Their mango lassi was pretty thick. Not sure it really quenched my thirst, but it did help cool down my tongue from the burrito. I also had a samosa. Maybe I'm just not a fan of samosas, but it seemed pretty dry when I went.

My four stars is basically for the burrito alone. They're other stuff is so-so, but when you go to the indian food truck, you go for the burrito.
author: Jeffrey M.

description: Once again, Yelp reviewers were right on point.  I've read some great reviews about the chicken tikka masala burrito and I just had to try it for myself.  And just like some other reviewers mentioned, the chicken itself was kinda dry but the curry flavoring more than makes up for it.  And even though the chicken was dry, the burrito as a whole was not.  Does that make sense?  I also enjoyed the samosas.  They counteracted the spiciness of the burrito perfectly.  I don't really do spicy so I'm glad I got the samosas.  So here's my verdict:  the burrito was flavorful and juicy enough to enjoy.  But if I didn't get the samosas, I think it would have eventually gotten too spicy for me.  And speaking of, when I asked the guy if there was a mild option, dude kinda yelled at me:  "There's only MEDIUM and MORE SPICY!  That's it!"  I was a little shocked that he seemed so annoyed.  All the other people at food trucks are always waaaaaaay friendly.  I mean, I'm sure he gets that question a lot but still, these are your customers.  Whatevs, I prolly wouldn't go back.  Even though it was tasty, I'm keeping it at 3 stars cuz homeboy needs to improve his 'tude.
author: Joe M.

description:
I have been a regular here for quite a while and really enjoy the Paneer Tikka Masala Burritos. However, they keep raising their prices. It cost around $5.50 for one burrito when I first came here. As of my last visit it had jumped to $8.

Quality and consistency seem to have declined over time as well. For example chickpeas are well cooked one visit but too hard the next and the amount of paneer in one burrito has dropped overall. Also, be sure to double-check that what you ordered is what you actually get. Two of my previous three orders have been incorrect (chicken, not paneer - veggies beware).  This never used to happen but then again none of the original staff still work in this truck.

Sadly, I think Curry Up Now has run its course for me. It was great while it lasted, but sometimes things start to go downhill once a business has reached a certain level of success.
author: Peter G.

description: Of the indian food trucks this is one of the better ones. Although the tikka masala sauce kind of takes over everything.  I wish the fries were not sweet potato fries and just normal fries.
author: Mike L.

description: Favorite food truck, hands down. Nothing beats the PTM. Curry just belongs in burritos. My only suggestion: less rice, more spice!!! It wouldn't hurt to throw in a little extra paneer, either...
author: Amelia V.

description:
Just got back from the OTG in Alameda.  I had the Sexy Fries with Pork Belly.  I understand i am the one who chooses what meat goes on top, but you're supposed to be the one that makes sure that no matter what i choose the flavors/textures, etc will blend well.

Message to Curry up now: Please utilize the pork belly the way its supposed to be used.  Maybe  a baked/broiled pressed pork belly.  You can even turn it into a hash, and then drizzle the curry sauce on top.  You can stew any cut of pork to make it fall off the bone tender.  If you decide to stew it, all you end up with is pork with fat greater than the size of the meat....not cool.
author: Arthur C.

description:
I'd never thought about combining a burrito with Indian food, but wow, what a combination.  You have got to try the tikka masala burrito.  Absolutely amazing!!!!!

One downside to this delectable treat, the line was 15 minutes long.
author: Morgan D.

description: My brother works in the financial district and I met him near his office for lunch. Curry Up Now was parked nearby with a huge line forming down the block so I decided I must try. Ordered the standard curry burrito and a mango lassi. It was good but I wasn't over impressed. I've had better tasty curry chicken. Curry Up Now is not much more than a novelty for me.
author: Lawrence N.

description: $7 vegan deconstructed samosa rocks my world.  Absolutely delicious, fast and inexpensive. Vegan burrito..not so much, but still good.  They take cards too which is nice.  I go like x2 a month.
author: Madeleine M.

description: I looove Curry Up Now!  It is litterally around the corner from my office and has some of the tastiest samosas that I've ever had (and biggest!)  I usually get a chicken tikka burrito, extra spicy, but sometimes simply opt for two samosas.  either way, I am a happy lil camper with my spicy mouthfuls of deliciousness and a Mexican Coke.
author: Rena H.

description: Can you say Chicken Tikka Masala Sexy Fries?!? The man who came up with this concoction is nothing short of a genius. The flavors go oh so well together it's like an exotic burst of deliciousness in my mouth...I'm eating these as I write...mostly eating until I finish. LOL Although they are scrumptions the CTM Sexy Fries are not the only thing on the menu that will get you going, the burritos are sure to put a smile on your face for the rest of the day even if you have to go back to work. I have yet to try the deconstructed samosa but with their track record I'm sure it will not dissapoint! I highly recommend this food truck because it really trumps the rest.
author: Selene M.

description:
I follow the food carts and trucks via twitter.  Unfortunately,  I don't live in the Mission and I don't work in South Park area so I don't really get a chance to try them out.  

When Curry Up Now announced they would be in the financial district and would take online orders, I jumped on the opportunity to try their food.  I placed our lunch orders online and asked my boyfriend to pick it up; since they park outside his work.  That day it took us almost an hour to pick up our lunch.  So why did I give them four stars?

Of course the food was awesome.  I had the chicken kathi roll.  It had a kick to it (which I'm learning to bear).  And when I checked my twitter and facebook account later, I saw a heartfelt apology from Curry Up Now.  Turns out they had some technical difficulties that day.  

Can't wait to try other items from their menu.
author: Johannah P.

description: I had the deconstructed veggie samosa and it was nice and spicy and I got the terrible brisket sandwich taste  from rib - whip out of me.
author: Chris D.

description: Given the consistent lines of daily grinders waiting for their taste of Indian "street food",  against my better judgment l decided to give in to the hype.  The 35 minute wait, entertainment of eaves dropping on conversations drenched with "first timer" anticipation, and finally the view of menu, with only two selections, proved unworthy.  Hmmmm samosa or tikka masala burrito?  Burrito it is....nice and hot in less than 5 minutes after ordering. Run back to my office. The anticipation is killing me. I settle in, unwrap the burrito and bite...into a mass of mushy unsalted rice and dried up chicken breast that was covered in sauce.  Yeah...I don't think so. Curry Up Now is a not!  I'm not so sure what all the hype is...
author: Angela V.

description: I'm not a fan of Indian food at all, but when it comes to Curry up now I'll always make an exception for the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito! It's huge.....filling, always spicy, but good spicy (if that makes any sense).  I think it's like $7...you can always share with a friend.
author: Diane L.

description:
ok, so i dont eat indian food... why? cuz i feel like my pores breathe out curry... i smell like curry... and afterwards i always feel heavy and major food coma... so... i NEVER get indian... that is... until maybe now...

came over to OTG civic center today for lunch and the smell of curry from curry up now was SO enticing... but typical me... NO, i'm not gonna get it... but my co worker said... it's good... how bout you get a cuban sandwich and i'll get the burrito and we'll have them cut in half... okay... it's not gonna kill me.... 

got our food... sat down... froze our butts off in this 40 degree SF cold weather... and took my first bite of the burrito... cuz i figure... if it's not good... i can always rely back to my cuban... and surprise surprise... it was SO yummy!!! the rice was perfectly cooked... the chicken was not dry... the sauce was creamy and flavorful... not too pungent... ooooh... nom nom nom... it was SO good... this is where i'm thinking "damn! i shoulda gotten a whole one.... "
author: Kelly H.

description:
Wow!  What a wonderful addition to the Financial District lunch options.  I pre-ordered, to avoid the long wait, and I was very glad I did.  At noon, there had to be 30 people in line for food.  I had the CTM Burrito (spicy) with a samosa.  Even the samosa was spicy!  Next time, I'll skip the samosa simply because the burrito is more than enough food.  I found the burrito very flavorful and definitely spicy.  It was almost too hot, but I still go through it.

You can tell how bored people are with their everyday lunch choices these days.  This is a fresh, flavorful addition to the area.  I'm not sure I could handle it more than once a week, due to the food coma I'm experiencing right now.  But it was very tasty!  Yummmm.....
author: Stephanie R.

description:
I'm wandering around the SF Street Food festival, trying to decide which ridiculous line I want to wait in. Creme brulee, soba noodle soup, paneer tikka masala burrito... wait, paneer tikka masala burrito? My brain stopped, and I knew it had to be done.

It was worth the line, at least as much as anything ever is. The pickled onions were delicious, the chickpeas scattered throughout added great texture, the spiciness was right on target, and it was the perfect moistness while still managing to contain itself in its tortilla wrapper. 

I'll definitely be exploring the unabridged menu. 

P.S. The mango lassi was okay.
author: Robyn M.

description: This food truck parks near my old job in the FiDi and always has a long line,but it well worth the wait! I love the tika masala burrito and i LOVE how they let me customize mine (no onions). The flavor is on point and it is very spicy. I also come here for the samosas, which are always cooked perfectly.I suggest taking an early lunch to avoid the long lines
author: Nicky E.

description: Since I started working in the FiDi almost a year ago, I've been dying to try this food truck. It finally happened this past Monday. I went to it around 1pm, waiting in a semi short line, and was at the front in a matter of minutes. I got the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito, which is what I've been hearing and thinking about this entire time. It was really good! However I'm a HUGE sauce person, and I wish I would have had some chutney or something to put on it, the burrito would have been exponentially better :). But it was great, and it did not weigh me down like I thought it would. It IS huge, but I ate it at a pretty slow pace, and really enjoyed it. I will definitely come back to the food truck on Bush street, but maybe not for a while.
author: Dawn O.

description:
Had the CMT Burrito.  It was very flavorful, the chicken was moist, good balance of onions, garbanzo beans, rice, and cilantro.   Went for the "spicy," with some reluctance having read some of the posts on here.  If you don't shy away from spicy, you'll enjoy the heat of this thing.  It's not insane nearly-inedible spicy, but ya might sweat a little.  In the end, I'm glad I ordered it spicy...for now.  We'll see if I have to give an update in 6 hours or so.

The line was out of control.  About 20 people ahead of us.  Moved fairly quickly though.  Before I even got my drink, my double order was ready at the pick-up window.

The samosa wasn't anything to write home about and the mango lassin wasn't very good at all. 

I'll be back soon...even if I pay for it later.  I never learn.
author: Dave H.

description:
Came here for lunch yesterday at about 1:25. I was surprised to find a line of about 5 people - and about a half a dozen people waiting for their order so late in the lunch hour.  It did take a while for them to crank out the orders... Partially because they ran out of chicken for a little while and the girl taking orders was telling people it was going to be a 8-10 minute wait. 

I ordered the chicken tikka masala burrito (regular) and a samosa. Whole bill only came to 8.25 and it was A LOT of food.  It was definitely tasty, and the regular spice definitley had a kick to it. Definitley liked the meal, but don't know if I would wait so long again.
author: Kristy S.

description: Just a spicy Indian burrito, nothing much. The spicy is overtaking the taste.
author: Chellam C.

description: I wish I could give 3.5 stars. I've had their vegan burrito. I think it's officially called a hella vegan, but now I'm worried I'm remembering it wrong and just sound annoying. It's pretty tasty, but definitely heavy and unfortunately not too healthy. Their mango lassi is nice and tangy -- yum!
author: Olivia P.

description: I like Curry Up Now, but it's just really heavy. If you're looking for a lighter lunch option, this isn't the place. I tried the chicken tikka masala burrito and 30 minutes later, I just wanted to take a nap.
author: Kristen O.

description: Chicken Tikka Masala is real tasty.  I wish they had lamb or some lean beef option.  It doesnt take long to get your order.  I think the prices are a tad high for a food truck.  I go here about once a month.  not bad.
author: C O.

description: Tikki Masala burrito! For the last few bites, I have to force myself to finish cause it's just SO BIG. Great flavor with a bit of a kick. One time they made it kinda dry, but it's not supposed to be. It should be wet, almost drippy, and fresh. Line is worth it, and there usually is unless you go later (around 1:34pm or so.)
author: Ellenor L.

description: Curry Up is one of my favorite food trucks, and definitely the best of the 20 or so trucks that come by Sierra Point in Brisbane.  The deconstructed samosas (I get the paneer version) are delicious and flavorful, and the servers will make them spicy upon request.  I viewed and caught a whiff of the "Sexy Fries" today and will be ordering them the next time Curry Up comes around.
author: melita s.

description: Ehh, paneer tiki masala is much better in burrito form. Sorry sexy fries, you weren't worth $8, IMO.
author: Gina G.

description: Best Chicken Curry Burrito you'll ever find.Great fast staff that actually take the time to remember regular customers orders.
author: Kiba E.

description: cold garbonzo beans in my chicken tikka masala burrito. Watery masala sauce. ok veg samosa. everything was falling apart tho.
author: Shayenne G.

description:
This review is about 3 hours late, but I just woke up from my food coma and I was a little disoriented for a minute.  But now I'm back (back again), and ready to rock n' roll with this superstar review for Curry Up Now.

As you all now by now, C.U.N. is actually a food truck and not a restaurant.  So the menu choices are fairly limited, but from what I've seen today, you do get some delicious grub, and a fairly large portion, too.  For $12, I got the chicken tikka masala burrito, one samosa, and a mango lassi.  And I was impressed with all of them!  The samosa was fresh, crispy on the outside and all sorts of deliciousness on the inside.  The burrito itself was HUGE, had good flavor and a good ratio of rice to chicken.  I don't know who came up with the concept of tikka masala burrito, but that person was a freakin' genius!  Let's get them a Nobel prize already!  I know that there are a lot of food trucks and a handful of restaurants that do this kind of fusion burrito already (see Sushirrito for just one example), but not all of them do it right, and Curry Up Now definitely does it right.  Lastly, the mango lassi was just what the spice doctor ordered to wash down the fire in your mouth (both the samosa and the burrito had a good kick to them), and quell your sweet cravings. So that lassi actually does double-duty, and as someone who works in the pressure-cooker world of litigation, I appreciate a good multi-tasker. 

Ahhh, I can feel the food coma coming on in 10, 9, 8, ...
author: Meg P.

description: They park just outside of my buidling on Bush St in SF.  If you work anywhere nearby, I'm sure you've seen the line down the street...there's a good reason...it's damned good!   I'm only glad that they don't show up every day otherwise I would be surviving soley on the PTK.  No need to ask for spicey as the regular is already spicey enough.  I asked for spicey once and it was fairly intolerable.  On top of delicious food, Nimma (the pretty lady that takes the orders) is really nice...always has a smile for everyone.   Also, they just released an app for the Android that allows you to order in advance.
author: Jonathan P.

description:
On the surface, you see an eight-dollar Chipotle-sized Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito at a truck that, amazingly, accepts credit cards. Burrow beneath the foil and steaming tortilla encasement and discover the spicy and generously seasoned chicken and rice underneath. What kind of rice do they use?? It's almost as long as my little finger! I swear they looked more like noodles. 

My impression upon taking a first bite was that  the spice level was manageable, but it gradually got increasingly difficult to eat. My understanding is that you can ask for it to be extra spicy, but only do that if you're confident. I've tried the extra spicy one, and I nearly choked on the single bite I had.
author: Angela X.

description:
Disclosure: tried this place awhile ago

I came here with coworkers after seeing the article on urban daddy. This was a mistake. A big fat mistake.

I'd heard of Curry Up Now before and wanted to try their burritos. The problem was they're mostly based in the South Bay so I never had an opportunity.

So we went a little early, before they opened, and waited in the long line. You could order online and get your food early, too, but we didn't do that. Not that it would have made a difference.

Problem 1: They didn't open on time.
Problem 2: The line split into two. The express burrito line and the other line. "Are there two lines? What? Which one are we in?" Then, the idiocy of the lines. You could order a burrito in both lines and it doesn't matter if you ordered yours first. The burrito line gets it. I understand that line is meant to get their burritos faster, but seriously? I order my burrito way before someone else and they get theirs like 30 minutes before I do?
Problem 3: Those people who ordered early online? They still had to stand in line. It's great they still want to make the food fresh for those customers, but had I ordered early, and still needed to wait in line, and then had to wait for my food to be made... I'd be beyond pissed.
Problem 4: The guy taking orders? Oy vey. When we finally got to order, he took the order, looked toward the guys making the food, slowly made his way over to their wall, found a place to post it, then made his way back. He did this every. time. Every time.
Problem 5: Took forever to get our food after ordering. Like half an hour. This is after over an hour of waiting in line. I walked away, bought some kim bap from John's Snack and Deli, and shared it with my coworker as we waited for our truck food.

So disorganized. To the power of 10. It's not like they haven't been operating for a while.

... Anyhow, the food.

I liked my chicken tikka masala burrito. It was good. There are chickpeas instead of beans. That's cool, it's not like a regular burrito just with Indian flavors. Everything about it is Indian except for the tortilla. I'd eat it again.

But after a wait like that, did it rock my world? Hell to the no!

My coworkers and I have not yet returned. Would I go back? Eeeh... yeah, I would. The publicity did not help their service, and hopefully they've improved their system. It was a good burrito. I had it again at the Eat Real Festival, when there was no line.

But if I see a horde of people waiting to get their orders for this truck again I'm getting food elsewhere.
author: Amy N.

description: Great concept but I thought the actually chicken tikka masala filling was just average. If this was served at an actual restaurant, I would think it was subpar. It definitely filled me up though...I didn't even eat for the rest of the day because the burrito was so huge! If you're in the area...check it out but don't go out of your way to come here.
author: Krystal N.

description:
Headed to Curry Up Now with all the co-workers after we spotted the truck last week. Not a long line at 1:30 p.m. which was nice. 
Ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito. Let me say that I am NOT a spicy fan, so was slightly worried after hearing my coworkers try it out and immediately run for water. 
To my surprise, it was not that spicy at first, but as I moved down the burrito it was very spicy!

Quick service and very friendly people working there. Definitely will go back again but will be armed with some water or milk!
author: Jenna M.

description:
i was doing the usual thing and swaping tickets for beers at this years eat real festival when elaine, aka COSTCO! tossed me over this foil wrapped goodness. 

chicken tikki masala burrito. 

good.

fin.
author: Euge L.

description: Not being a fan of comfort food I avoided the sexy fries.  I was a bit underwhelmed by the tikka masala burrito.  i don't think the flavors mix well with a burrito wrap and the masala itself which was just way too curried.  I get the concept but not sure I am tempted to try another lunch experiment here.
author: Jake S.

description: Tastes like very subpar curry in a tortilla. Awful food, awful service, and an awful wait time.
author: Chris B.

description: After inevitably revisiting CurryUp now - the spice level is once again appropriate. Delicious and spicy Indian curry wrapped into a portable burrito format results in satisfying culinary delight. For fastest service - preorder the food online.
author: Artem D.

description: I finally tried the Curry Up Now truck today at Off the Grid: Civic Center. The verdict? Chicken tikka masala burrito coma. My burrito was bursting with fantastic flavor but they need to get a lesson in wrapping - mine was a bit loose and the tortilla had a hard time containing all the masala goodness within.
author: phil h.

description:
taste-tacular!  

The line can be long, but I've found that they tend to have lots of items ready to hand to you as you pay.  Staff is friendly, and way more patient than I would be if I had to take orders and hand out food to people who sometimes can't be bothered to get off their cell phones for a minute.

They have a several different items to please meat-eater and vegan alike, and I'm a huge fan of the deconstructed samosas and the "hella" vegan burrito.  

The potato masala is flavorful and accented with pickled onions AND little crumbled bits of samosa, too!  The rice is nicely flavored to take off the heat.  Burritos are huge, but wrapped well, and tend to stay together.

I've so far gotten my burrito spicy twice, and it's excellent (albeit a tad scary at times) if you like the heat!  If you're unsure, then you probably don't.

Last time I was there I saw that they have an iPhone app, on which you can order in advance and then swing by to pick up.  The app itself is a bit slow, but I just tend to go outside lunch rush time anyway.
author: Jenni S.

description: Tikka masala burrito!!!! The best thing I've had in a long ass time. I'm still dreaming about this a week after my first Off the Grid last Friday. OMG. It was to die for good. It's spicy as hell, and yes, you might pay for it later, but I'd do it all over again, and again and again. Inventive and delicious is a rare combo to master, but something about the marriage to a flour tortilla takes this to a whole other level. YUMMO.
author: Vanessa Y.

description: We discovered Curry Up Now at the Fort Mason Off the Grid almost a year ago, and it's still one of my favorite food trucks.  I've had the paneer tikka masala burrito several times, and it's consistently delicious and filling (and by filling I mean I have a giant food baby by the time I eat 3/4 of this thing).  The line here is generally long, but it's worth the wait!
author: Samantha P.

description: Indian food in a tortilla. How come we didn't think of this a long time ago? I tried the chicken tikka Marsala burrito....and it was goooood. Great taste, super fresh, and generous portions for a $7.00 burrito. The line was 20 people deep, but it moved fast because they have 5 people working in the truck.
author: Matt M.

description: I finally had a CUN burrito.  Had the spicy chicken tikka masala burrito and boy was it good. My cousin had been talking about the burrito forever, but the truck was never close enough to me. I love spicy, but this spicy is the kind that builds up in your mouth. The burrito was a little loose, so it had to be eaten with a fork and knife. It was super tasty, but half a burrito was just the right serving size. I also tried the Sexy Fries, sweet potato fries with chicken, cheese and sauce (sorry, I forgot what kind of sauce it was). I do not like sweet potato anything, but this was good. The fries weren't over fried and the sweetness cut the heat from the burrito.
author: Adelina W.

description: WOW  - The chicken tikka masala burrito was the best thing I have eaten in a long time!
author: Shelly R.

description: Crazy busy (at 12:15 on a Friday) but worth it.  Just tried the Paneer Kathi roll and a mango lassi.  Paneer is perfect, tender, not falling apart.  A little spicy.  Could use a touch of salt.  Otherwise unreal.
author: Jeremy B.

description: I like Indian food but for some reason everything I had was sub-par. The Chicken Tikka Massala burrito which had a kick to it but not the kick I wanted. (you know the kick that makes you want more spanking) I had to down the spicy taste with my Mango Lassi. The drink was good, but not great. I guess I'm not use to the thick gooey texture. I think by adding some ice cubes, it can probably taste really refreshing but sadly no ice cubes were within my reach. I also had the samosa. I guess I forgot to tell them to hold the grease because it was super dark in coloring, drenched with extra saturated fat. I guess if you can get past the first layer, then the filling was pretty savory. I may have to come back and try the deconstructed samosa cuz it's looks really interesting appearance wise.
author: May B.

description: Dude!  Need I say more?!  Your Tikka Marsala Burritos are OTH!!  We ate one per day PLUS FOUR MORE to go for our lunches this week!  You need to venture outside your usual areas so everyone can get love too!  ;)
author: Simone F.

description:
I just wrote a scathing review for an Indian restaurant, and I realized I should be thankful we have trucks like Curry Up Now. 
Delicious food that makes you feel like your money was well spent. I had the 'sexy fries' with paneer tikka masala -- drool worthy stuff. I ordered online and that helped me skip the long long line. Nice friendly staff as well!
author: Pavithra K.

description: I had the chicken tikka masala burrito. Pretty spicy. Large chunks of chicken. Very Filling. Overall: pretty decent.
author: Desmond N.

description: Per usual, the huge line in front of this SF 'establishment' was right on the money.  Chicken tikka masala burrito bomb.  Big, spicy, delicious.  I'll wait a few extra minutes while my coworkers have already begun to devour their mediocre meals so I can reign supreme when this delicacy is ready for the taking.
author: William B.

description: The veggie version of the Chicken Tikka Masala burrito, the Paneer Tikka Masala burrito has garbanzo beans and paneer with curry sauce and rice.  I asked for it spicy and mouth was on fire.   The key is to pack up some free yogurt by the drinks  to put the fire out.
author: Wakako U.

description:
no no no no no.  never again.

i feel sick.  i dont like it.

this burrito was 80% rice anyways... there were a few chunks of chicken, and a bean here and there.  it's really overrated. 

im gonna go puke now.

"?"
-?
author: John B R.

description:
I was skeptical at first to try Indian food from a truck. Although I love my Oakland taco trucks, the idea of having any other food from a truck was kind of a surprise to me. (Aside from Kara's Kupcakes)

Today I decided to give it a shot. So I walked over to the truck on my lunch, which took me about 5-7 minutes... I work over by the Embarcadero Centers and from the distance I was really hoping the walk wasn't for nothing. The line was fairly long as I approached the truck, so I thought damn! I'm going to be late going back to work. The line went by SO FAST! I was shocked! When I ordered my DECONSTRUCTED SAMOSA W/ CHICKEN it was ready in 2.5 seconds (literally). I got to the office and tried my new finding, and wa-la!!! I am A FAN. 

The deconstructed samosa is REALLY GOOD!

I will be coming back for more!
author: Kaye C.

description: I did a task through taskrabbit.com where a sender posted a task asking someone to wait in like at Curry Up Now, grab them lunch, and then deliver it to their house. Once I got up to order, though, they didn't have one of the burritos that this person had ordered, the Special K. Well, upon asking very politely, they offered to make it for a dollar more which was great! They were really fast, efficient, and very very friendly! A-OK in my eye.
author: Erika D.

description: I went vegan for lent and had the "hella vegan" burrito. Omg it was amazing! I got it twice during lent, line isn't super slow, and the guys making everything are super friendly. Highly recommend this delicious food truck!
author: Larissa S.

description: delicious burrito, but my favorite was the somosa.  try it out.. you wont be sorry!
author: tom w.

description: Boy oh boy do I dig Curry Up. I try to venture around and find new, exciting and valuable food is SF, but I keep running back for a P.T.M. burrito and a samosa. They're a little inconsistent with texture, spice, etc, but it's kind of endearing because it screams "I was made today!" They should put a boot on this truck so it never leaves!
author: Alex E.

description:
3.5 stars.

SJ Eats was a major fail for us. 2+ hour wait to sample food at various food trucks including this one. I'm so glad they have about three Curry Up Now trucks in different cities everyday during the week so that I was able to finally try them and they did not disappoint! The Chicken Tiki Masala Burrito and Chicken Deconstructed Samosa were my favorites. The burrito had a lot of spices and beware, if you order spicy, dude no joke it's pretty spicy! I have a tolerance for spicy foods, but I could feel it burning going down. You'll need to get the Lassi like we did to sooth down the burning sensation. It was so much better spicy though, so if you can take the heat, order spicy! The deconstructed samosa had a lot of spice as well and even though we ordered spicy, our tongues weren't on fire like the burrito, it was actually the perfect level of spiciness. It had a wee bit too many garbanzo beans though. The samosa didn't impress us though, stuffed with too much potatoes and didn't come with the mint sauce that I usually like to top it off with. Friendly servers, I'll be back!
author: Karen L.

description: You are so missing out if you haven't tried the awesomeness that is Curry Up Now.  Not only is their food authentic enough to make me want to take my cousins straight from the homeland, but it's actually interesting fare - not the run of the mill chaat, buffet, or dosa house.  Instead, how about a  deconstructed samosa?  Paneer quesadilla, anyone? Or just go old-school Bombay and get a Kathi roll.  Any way you play it, just be sure to plan your day according to how spicy your food is.  I got the spicy paneer burrito, and I think I stopped breathing after 3 bites.  I guess it doesn't matter how brown you are, spicy is spicy, and you can either hang or you can't.  Regardless, it's a characteristic worth building... just for this food if nothing else!
author: Maulie D.

description: Ummm delish!  Try the Chicken Tikka Masala Burrito!  So good and spicy.  Its big too....that's what she said!  Get it and love it.  Also, the samosas were sooo good.  Greasy but great.  Try them both and share away!
author: Jordan S.

description: We got the chicken torta with guacamole and mint sauce.  We had high expectations, but were disappointed:  The chicken was super dry and the sandwich overall was just bland and ordinary.  The accompanying sweet potato fries were a bit soggy.  I will say, though, that there was a long line and the folks inside were friendly.
author: Elena L.

description: When I arrived at this place, the line stretched around the block. While definitely a minor inconvenience, nothing is more indicative of the tastiness of a restaurants food like the length of the line of hungry customers. I ordered a chicken tikka masala burrito, an idea I can only describe as pure genious, and walked around the block to some tables to enjoy my delicious smelling treat. The burrito was delicious, perfectly spicy, generously portioned and all around satisfying. For my first food truck experience in the city, I can't imagine it gets much better!
author: David H.

description: The Chicken Tikka Masala burrito is probably one of the best things I have ever had. And when they say spicy, they mean spicy. Personally, I think the hotter the better. I like to be uncomfortable when I eat spicy food, it's part of the experience. Curry Up Now never fails to disappoint. The burrito is filling as hell too.
author: Alfredo A.

description: The chicken tikka masala burrito really does live up to its hype.  It's big, delicious, spicy, and full of flavor.  Nevermind that the scent you emit after is not so pleasant, it's so worth it.
author: K V.

description: Tried their samosas while I was at SF's weekly food truck gathering, Off The Grid (which is awesome).  Took a bite, threw the rest away.  Way too doughy.  Not crispy at all.  It was just chewy, and doughy, tasteless.  The curry inside was dry.  Disappointed.
author: suzanne l.

description: The heart has been healed! I love the fact that Rana, the owner messaged me =) It's good to see an owner that truly cares! Now to bring my tummy back haha! NOM NOM NOM!
author: Albert K.

description: Chicken Tikka Masala burrito??? Hell yeah! This place is a favorite amongst my co-workers and the food is super tasty.  It's a bit spicy/hot tho..I may bring a spare t-shirt to work the next time I order one.
author: Jeff M.

description: Found the CurryUp Now truck by chance. I was in San Francisco's Financial District at lunch time, walked out of the bank at the right time, and smelled the curry. Mmm... I had the chicken curry burrito. It had just the right amount of heat and satisfied my mean appetite. Dhanyavaad.
author: Greg J.

description: The chicken tikka masala burrito was like someone took chunks of white meat chicken, baked them until cottony and dessicated, soaked them in Naan & Curry's grease trap and wrapped them in a tortilla along with a couple of shakers of salt.  An Anglo-Indian-Cal-Mexican culinary abortion.
author: Suo L.

description: About two years ago, I used to crave this place daily. Now I barely go once a month. The quality has gone down hill and prices have gone up. The only good thing to come out of all this is that the line isn't as long anymore.
author: M Y.

description:
they have the right blends of spices, which makes their dishes very aromatic and flavorful.  they are also serious about what they deliver when they say spicy.  often when i order spicy i add extra hot sauce since it doesn't even tickle my tastebuds.  i ordered their chicken tikka masala spicy, and they were all business.  i'm talking about tear jerking, nose dripping spicy goodness, so good that you become a masochist going for the next bite.  good thing i got some raita to cool my mouth down.  

i'm definitely a fan of CUP, and if i spot their cart again i don't think i'll be able to contain my masochistic spicy side.
author: Sheri N.

description: Chicken Tikka Masala burrito.....awesome!
author: Steve K.

description:
First time review.  Here's the short version:

Good concept, well executed, tasty (but not terribly adventurous) food.  4.5 stars for that.

Cashier = Douchenozzle Extraordinaire!  When you have posted "Add Samosa + Mango Lassi for $4" and I order it, don't get in my face because I didn't read your mind that you had run out of lassi (it was only 1:10 pm).  "I'm out of mango lassi," he said like a Big Old Queen.  When it's not really clear that you have a CHICKEN tikka masala burrito and a PANEER tikka masala burrito, don't get all pissy about it, man-girl.  1 star for you.

I'm going to be generous and give them 3 stars.  There's a good chance that I'll get food from here again, but will pay one of my co-workers to pick it up next time - no douchenozzles for me, thanks very much.

I'll happily stand in line at the Wiener's Circle in Chicago for 30 minutes and take abuse from their cashiers (who are notorious for it), but am really not interested in spending even 5 minutes in line during my lunch hour if there's a Big Douche waiting to take my order.

I really dislike bad service.  It makes or breaks the meal.
author: Dennis H.

description: I checked Curry Up Now's hours listed here and I was so stoked when I saw that they're open on Saturdays. I trekked from my apartment all the way to FiDi just to find out the opposite! :( But I'm still giving them 4 stars coz the chicken tikka masala burrito is as good as everyone says it is! I didn't really care for the deconstructed samosa. There's always a line but the wait isn't long. Can't wait to try the sexy fries!!
author: Kimberly L.

description:
Chicken tikka masala burrito ($8) was good (anything wrapped with a tortilla is great) but the filling just got to be far too saucy and left me wanting some plain rice.

I actually liked the veggie samosa better, though it's definitely not as flavorful as the burrito.  1 for $2 or 2 for $3.

The line moves really quickly, I got my food like 30 seconds after I paid.

I'd go back but probably only to try something else!
author: S L.
